title: Robust Equilibria in Generic Extensive form Games

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We prove the 2-player, generic extensive-form case of the conjecture of Govindan and Wilson (1997a,b) and Hauk and Hurkens (2002) stating that an equilibrium component is essential in every equivalent game if and only if the index of the component is nonzero. This provides an index-theoretic characterization of the concept of hyperstable components of equilibria in generic extensive-form games, first formulated by Kohlberg and Mertens (1986). We also illustrate how to compute hyperstable equilibria in multiple economically relevant examples and show how the predictions of hyperstability compare with other solution concepts.

## 1. INTRODUCTION

Hyperstable equilibria, as formulated in Kohlberg and Mertens (1986), are those Nash equilibria that are robust to perturbations not only of the payoffs of the given game, but also to equivalent games of the given game (i.e., games that are obtained by adding duplicate strategies). In other words, it is a solution concept characterized by two simple properties: (1) robustness to payoff perturbations (strategic essentiality); (2) the principle that equivalent games should have equivalent solutions (also known as invariance).

Hyperstable equilibria constitute an important step in Kohlberg and Mertens' stability program as the first equilibrium concept to satisfy the basic properties of existence, sequential rationality, invariance and iterated dominance, making it an appealing refinement of Nash equilibria. Even if hyperstable equilibria do not always satisfy admissibility, in generic extensive-form games hyperstable equilibrium outcomes do satisfy all those properties. ${ }^{\ddagger}$ However, hyperstability is a highly intractable concept. Not only does its definition require robustness to payoff perturbations in the base game - which is in itself hard to check - but also in every equivalent game to the base game.

In this paper we provide a characterization of hyperstable equilibria that makes it a more operational concept, as we intend to illustrate in the last section with a series of examples. This characterization dispenses with the need of considering equivalent games to the base game and, in several instances, makes the problem of checking for robustness to payoff perturbations almost trivial.

This gain in simplicity is achieved by formulating the characterization in terms of a concept of topological fixed point theory called the index of fixed points, which we now explain. In algebraic topology, tools such as the fixed point index are developed to study and distinguish among fixed points. In particular, when studying fixed points in an abstract setting, it is also of interest to identify robustness properties of the fixed points with respect to perturbations of their fixed-point maps. A topologically essential fixed point of a map is a point such that every nearby map has a close-by fixed point. Topologically essential fixed points do not always exist, ${ }^{2}$ but considering the sets of fixed points of a given map, one can extend the definition of topological essentiality from points to connected components of fixed points: ${ }^{3}$ a connected component of the set of fixed points is topologically essential if for sufficiently small perturbations of the fixed-point map, there are fixed points close to the component. Topologically essential components can be identified by an integer number called their index (cf. O'Neill (1953)). The process through which this number is assigned is rather involved and will be explained later in more detail, but the important fact is that a component of fixed points is topologically essential if and only if the index is non-zero.

In a game-theoretic context, and for some function whose fixed points coincide with the Nash equilibria of a game, an index can therefore be assigned to every component of Nash equilibria in mixed strategies, and simple properties of the index of fixed points guarantee that at least one topologically essential component of equilibria exists. The conjecture that the strategically essential components coincide with those with nonzero index (Govindan and Wilson, 1997a,b), i.e. the topologically essential components, was disproved by Hauk and Hurkens (2002) by means of a counterexample. They recast the conjecture and hypothesized that the hyperstable components are precisely those that have nonzero index. We show that this is indeed the case for generic two-player extensive-form games. Our notion of genericity implies the commonly used property of extensive-form games according to which each connected component of equilibria in mixed strategies induces a single outcome in an extensive-form game. Therefore, our characterization can be seen as identifying the Nash equilibrium outcomes of an extensive-form game which are hyperstable. While intuitively every topologically essential Nash equilibrium component should be hyperstable, this result implies that the space of perturbations considered in the definition of hyperstability i.e. payoff perturbations - is as rich as the one used by topological essentiality, i.e. the space of perturbations of a map whose fixed points are the equilibria of a game.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ Consider the identity map from the interval $[0,1]$ to itself. Any point in $[0,1]$ is a fixed point of the map, but if we consider uniform perturbations of this map to near-by maps, none of the points of $[0,1]$ is robust.
    ${ }^{3}$ O'Neill (1953) shows that a minimal topologically essential fixed point set of an Euclidean space must be a connected component of the set of fixed points, thus justifying the formulation of topological essentiality to connected components of fixed points.

A similar result was proved by Govindan and Wilson (2005), henceforth GW, for arbitrary games. However, to obtain such a characterization they require a strengthening of hyperstability beyond the combination of invariance and robustness to payoff perturbations. GW call such a concept uniform hyperstability. ${ }^{4}$

As mentioned above, only information about the game under study is necessary to verify if a component is topologically essential. Indeed, Shapley (1974) shows that the index of equilibria in generic two-player games can be computed by a simple formula that only depends on parameters of the game. Balthasar (2009) generalized this formula to include non-generic two player games. Even if such formulas can be useful, for many relevant game-theoretical applications in the literature, it is enough to use the properties of the index to know if it is different from zero and, given our result, verify whether a component is hyperstable. ${ }^{5}$

From an axiomatic perspective, our result can be interpreted as providing an index theoretic characterization for the solution concept that, for each (generic two-player extensiveform) game selects all (closed and connected) subsets of Nash equilibria that satisfy (1) invariance and (2) robustness to payoff perturbations. A component of equilibria with nonzero index is known to be robust in every equivalent game, so a solution concept that selects the collection of equilibrium components with non-zero index is both invariant and robust to payoff perturbations. Conversely, if a solution concept selects all (closed and connected) sets of Nash equilibria that are invariant and robust to payoff perturbations then the selected solutions must be connected components of Nash equilibria. ${ }^{6}$ Furthermore, our main result implies that any zero index component is not robust in some equivalent game. Hence, all selected solutions are connected components with non-zero index.

In parallel to the developments in the strategic stability literature, the index of equilibria has also been used independently as a tool to select equilibria with interesting properties, especially with regards to their dynamic stability. Ritzberger (1994) formulated the index of equilibria for the replicator dynamics and presented some useful applications in game theory, including highlighting that non-zero index components of equilibria satisfy a number of desirable properties. Demichelis and Ritzberger (2003) obtained a necessary condition for the asymptotic stability of equilibria in dynamic adjustment processes that is formulated in terms of the index of equilibria. More recently, McLennan (2016) argued for the selection of equilibria with index +1 on both experimental and theoretical grounds, while Govindan et al. (2023) provided game-theoretic characterization for these. A natural question stemming from this strand of the literature is: what does the index precisely mean in game-theoretic terms? More precisely, while one can use non-zero index equilibria as a selection criterion to guarantee interesting properties for the selected equilibria, such a criterion is purely topological and may imply properties that are game-theoretically undesirable. Our main result provides an answer to this question by formulating the precise combination of game-theoretical properties that characterize non-zero index equilibria and define the classical concept of hyperstability.

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

This paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents all the required notation and definitions. In particular, it introduces the necessary properties of the index that will be applied throughout the paper and states the main result. Section 3 defines one the main objects of the analysis-the excluded game associated to an equilibrium outcome. Section 4 lays down the precise genericity assumptions under which our main result holds. We prove our main result in Section 5. Such a proof is divided in three steps and is accompanied by a running example to illustrate the main ideas. To finalize, Section 6, contains an illustration on how to compute the index in many economically relevant examples, allowing to identify non-hyperstable equilibria. The Appendix contains additional definitions and proofs that do not appear in the main text.

# 1.1. An example 

To illustrate the main ideas of the result and the proof, consider the entry game in Figure 1. To analyze the example, we use two simple facts about the index of equilibria. The first one is that the index of a strict equilibrium is +1 . The second is that the sum of the indexes is always +1 . The game in Figure 1 has two components of Nash equilibria. In the first component, player 1 moves In and then both players play $(L, \ell)$ in the subgame. Hence, this component is made of a single strategy profile that, furthermore, is a strict equilibrium as any deviation by either player leaves such player with a strictly lower payoff. (Note as well that $(L, \ell)$ is also a strict equilibrium in the subgame.) Since the index of a strict equilibrium is +1 and indexes must add up to one, the second component must have zero index. This second component is such that player 1 moves Out with probability one and player 2 plays $r$ in the subgame with probability at least $1 / 3$. We call the set of strategy profiles in the subgame such that player 2 plays in this way the supporting polytope of the component because it supports on-path play, i.e., at any point in this component player 2 cannot affect the outcome and player 1 is at most indifferent between Out and $L$ when player 2 plays $r$ with probability exactly equal to $1 / 3$.

Figure 2. Modifying function $f$ to eliminate two fixed points with indexes adding up to zero.
![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

We can think of the "Out"-component as excluding the subgame, and of the supporting polytope as containing behavior in the subgame that supports that exclusion. The supporting polytope contains two Nash equilibria of the subgame, $(R, r)$ and the mixed strategy profile $\left(\frac{3}{4} L+\frac{1}{4} R, \frac{1}{4} \ell+\frac{3}{4} r\right)$. When considering the subgame in isolation, the former equilibrium has index +1 because it is strict, and the latter has index -1 because the sum of the indexes in the subgame must be +1 and the other two equilibria are strict ( $(R, r)$ as just mentioned, and $(L, \ell)$ ). If we extend the notion of index of a component of equilibria to the index of a (suitably chosen) neighborhood by adding the indexes of the components included in the neighborhood, we note that the index of any sufficiently small neighborhood of the supporting polytope must be zero.

Given a game, we show in Section 5.2 that if the index of a neighborhood is zero, then there exists a payoff perturbation of an equivalent game with no equilibrium inside the neighborhood and such that, payoffs outside such a neighborhood are as close as we want to those in the original game. Figure 2 illustrates. The interval $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$ contains two fixed points in which the function cuts the $45^{\circ}$ line from below (index -1 ) and then from above (index +1 ). ${ }^{7}$ We can pull the graph of $f$ so that the new function whose graph coincides with the dashed line when $x \in\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$ has no fixed point in $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$. Thus, if $G$ is the subgame in Figure 1, there exists an equivalent game $\hat{G}$ (i.e., a game which is obtained by adding finitely many pure strategies that are duplicates of mixed strategies of $G$ ) and a perturbation of it $\hat{G}^{\delta}$ with no equilibria in the (subset of the strategy profile equivalent to the) supporting polytope and such that payoffs outside that polytope are at least $\delta$-close to those in $\hat{G}$. The existence of $\hat{G}^{\delta}$ relies on the techniques developed in Govindan and Wilson (2005), but it is not an exact application of their result, as our Appendix C demonstrates.

With this information, consider the extensive-form game in Figure 3. Nature moves first. With probability $1-\varepsilon$ players play the original entry game but with the subgame $G$ replaced by the equivalent subgame $\hat{G}$. With probability $\varepsilon$, players play the perturbed game $\hat{G}^{\delta}$ that

[^0]:    ${ }^{7}$ In this one-dimensional case, if $x^{*}$ is a fixed point, the index of $x^{*}$ is $\operatorname{Ind}_{f}\left(x^{*}\right)=\left.\operatorname{sign}\left(\frac{\partial f d-f \forall x)}{\partial x}\right|_{x=x^{*}}\right)$

Figure 3. A game equivalent to that in Figure 1 when $\varepsilon=0$
![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)
does not have an equilibrium in the supporting polytope. Player 1 observes the move of Nature, but player 2 does not know if she is playing because Nature chose the perturbed game $\bar{G}^{\delta}$ or because player 1 chose In. This is captured by player 2's information set connecting nodes representing games $\bar{G}$ and $\bar{G}^{\delta}$. Note that when $\varepsilon=0$ this extensive-form game is equivalent to the game in Figure 1. ${ }^{8}$ It can be proved that when $\varepsilon$ is small enough this equivalent game does not have any Nash equilibrium component in which player 1 plays Out. Intuitively, if there were such outcome, player 2 would have to be playing in the (set equivalent to the) supporting polytope - so that Out is a best reply for player 1. Knowing that, in such an equilibrium, if player 2 is called to move, then she knows it is because Nature chose $\bar{G}^{\delta}$. But such a game does not have an equilibrium in the supporting polytope. We can similarly prove that there is no sequence of equilibria in which player 1's strategy converges to playing Out with probability one as $\varepsilon$ converges to zero. Hence, when $\varepsilon$ is small enough, Figure 3 gives us a perturbation of a game equivalent to the entry game of Figure 1 with no equilibrium close to the zero-index "Out"-component.

In the rest of the paper we show that under some generic conditions every key step in this example generalizes. In particular, given a two-player game and a component that induces a unique outcome, we can always define an "excluded game" (which is not necessarily a subgame) whose supporting polytope (capturing behavior in the excluded game that prevents it from being reached) has zero index in such an excluded game. And with that, we can construct a game equivalent to the original and a perturbation of its payoffs analogous to Figure 3 with the property that the resulting game has no equilibrium close to the zero index component.

# 2. Preliminaries
### 2.1. Equivalent strategies, equivalent normal-form games

A finite two-player normal-form game $\mathbb{G} \equiv\left(S_{1}, S_{2}, \mathbb{G}_{1}, \mathbb{G}_{2}\right)$ is a four-tuple where, for each $n=1,2$, player $n$ 's finite set of pure strategies is $S_{n}$ and $\mathbb{G}_{n}: S_{1} \times S_{2} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is player $n$ 's payoff function. As usual, $\Sigma_{n} \equiv \Delta\left(S_{n}\right)$ is player $n$ 's set of mixed strategies and $S \equiv S_{1} \times S_{2}$ and $\Sigma \equiv \Sigma_{1} \times \Sigma_{2}$ are, respectively, the sets of pure and mixed strategy profiles. We also denote

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{8}$ More precisely, the game with $\varepsilon=0$ is equivalent to the original game in the sense that both have the same reduced normal forms.

by $\mathbb{G}_{n}$ the multilinear extension of player $n$ 's payoff function to the set of mixed strategy profiles $\Sigma$.

Two strategies $\sigma_{n}, \sigma_{n}^{\prime} \in \Sigma_{n}$ are equivalent if for both $m=1,2$ we have $\mathbb{G}_{m}\left(\sigma_{n}, s_{-n}\right)=$ $\mathbb{G}_{m}\left(\sigma_{n}^{\prime}, s_{-n}\right)$ for all $s_{-n} \in S_{-n}$. Given $\mathbb{G}=\left(S_{1}, S_{2}, \mathbb{G}_{1}, \mathbb{G}_{2}\right)$, the reduced normal-form of $\mathbb{G}$ is a normal-form game $\mathbb{G}^{\prime}=\left(S_{1}^{\prime}, S_{2}^{\prime}, \mathbb{G}_{1}, \mathbb{G}_{2}\right)$ that is obtained from $\mathbb{G}$ by eliminating pure strategies that are equivalent to some existing mixed strategy. That is, $S_{n}^{\prime} \subseteq S_{n}$ and if $s_{n} \in S_{n} \backslash S_{n}^{\prime}$ then there is $\sigma_{n} \in \Sigma_{n}^{\prime} \equiv \Delta\left(S_{n}^{\prime}\right)$ that is equivalent to $s_{n}$. Note that, up to relabeling of strategies, the reduced normal-form of a finite game is unique.
Definition 2.1. Two games $\overline{\mathbb{G}}$ and $\mathbb{G}$ are equivalent if they have the same reduced normalform.

Given two equivalent games $\mathbb{G}=\left(S_{1}, S_{2}, \mathbb{G}_{1}, \mathbb{G}_{2}\right)$ and $\overline{\mathbb{G}}=\left(\bar{S}_{1}, \bar{S}_{2}, \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{1}, \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{2}\right)$ we extend the notion of equivalence between strategy profiles in the same game to equivalence of strategy profiles in equivalent games. Say that $\bar{\sigma}_{n} \in \bar{\Sigma}_{n}$ and $\sigma_{n} \in \Sigma_{n}$ are equivalent if there exists a strategy $\sigma_{n}^{\prime}$ in their (common) reduced normal-form game such that $\bar{\sigma}_{n}$ is equivalent to $\sigma_{n}^{\prime}$ (both viewed as strategy profiles in $\overline{\mathbb{G}}$ ) and $\sigma_{n}$ is equivalent to $\sigma_{n}^{\prime}$ (both viewed as strategy profiles in $\mathbb{G}$ ). If $\mathbb{G}$ and $\overline{\mathbb{G}}$ are two equivalent games we say profile $\sigma \in \Sigma$ is equivalent to profile $\bar{\sigma} \in \bar{\Sigma}$ if for each player $n$, the strategy $\sigma_{n}$ is equivalent to $\bar{\sigma}_{n}$. A subset $T \subset \Sigma$ is equivalent to $\bar{T} \subset \bar{\Sigma}$, if for each $\sigma \in T$ there exists $\bar{\sigma} \in \bar{T}$ such that $\sigma$ is equivalent to $\bar{\sigma}$ and for each $\bar{\sigma} \in \bar{T}$ there exists $\sigma \in T$ such that $\bar{\sigma}$ is equivalent to $\sigma$.

# 2.2. Extensive-form games 

We introduce notation and basic definitions. For a formal definition of extensive-form game with perfect recall see, e.g., Osborne and Rubinstein (1994). Consider a two-player finite game tree with perfect recall $\Gamma \equiv(T,<, U, A, \varrho)$. The set of nodes is $T$ and $<$ denotes the precedence relation in the tree. The set of terminal nodes is $Z \subset T$. The collection $U$ is a partition of $T \backslash Z$ into information sets of players and Nature. The set $U_{n} \subset U$ is the collection of information sets for player $n=0,1,2$, where player 0 represents Nature. (Every element in $U_{0}$ is a singleton.) The set of all actions in the game is $A$ and $A_{n}(u)$ represents player $n$ 's set of actions available at her information set $u \in U_{n}$. Let $A_{n} \equiv \bigcup_{u \in U_{n}} A_{n}(u)$ be the entire set of player $n$ 's actions. Moves of Nature are given by the function $\varrho$ that, to every $u \in U_{0}$, assigns a completely mixed probability distribution on $A_{0}(u)$.

For $n=1,2$, player $n$ 's set of pure strategies is $S_{n} \equiv\left\{s: U_{n} \rightarrow A_{n} \mid s(u) \in A_{n}(u)\right\}$ and her mixed strategy set is $\Sigma_{n} \equiv \Delta\left(S_{n}\right)$. Hence, we have the sets of strategy profiles $S \equiv S_{1} \times S_{2}$ and $\Sigma=\Sigma_{1} \times \Sigma_{2}$. Since we only consider games with perfect recall, Kuhn's theorem implies that we can work with behavior strategies whenever convenient. Given player $n=1,2$, a behavior strategy $b_{n}=\left(b_{n}(i)\right)_{i \in A_{n}}$ satisfies $\left(b_{n}(i)\right)_{i \in A_{n}(u)} \in \Delta\left(A_{n}(u)\right)$ for every $u \in U_{n}$. We let $B_{n}$ be player $n$ 's set of behavioral strategies.

For a fixed two-player game tree $\Gamma$, the space of games is $\mathscr{G} \equiv \mathbb{R}^{2|Z|}$. A game $G \in \mathscr{G}$ assigns payoff $G_{n}(z)$ to player $n$ at final node $z$. We refer to the extensive-form game defined by $\Gamma$ and terminal payoffs $G$ simply by $G$. The space of outcomes is $\Delta(Z)$, where an outcome $Q \in \Delta(Z)$ assigns probability $Q(z)$ to $z$.

Given action $a \in A$ the set of terminal nodes that come after action $a$ is $Z(a)$. Similarly, given an information set $u \in U$ we let $Z(u)$ be the set of terminal nodes that come after

some action available at $u$. We denote expressions $Q(Z(\alpha))$ and $Q(Z(u))$ simply as $Q(\alpha)$ and $Q(u)$. Given a profile of mixed strategies $\sigma \in \Sigma$ the induced outcome when players play according to $\sigma$ is $\mathbb{P}(\cdot \mid \sigma) \in \Delta(Z)$. With abuse of notation we also let $G: \Delta(Z) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ denote the expected utility function associated with game $G \in \mathscr{G}$. The normal-form representation of $G$ is $\mathbb{G}=\left(S_{1}, S_{2}, \mathbb{G}_{1}, \mathbb{G}_{2}\right)$ where, for each $n=1,2$, we have $\mathbb{G}_{n}(s)=G_{n}(\mathbb{P}(\cdot \mid s))$ for all $s \in S$.

# 2.3. Index Theory 

The fixed point index contains information about the robustness of fixed points of a map when such a map is perturbed to a nearby map. Since Nash equilibria are fixed points, we can apply index theory to them (cf. Ritzberger, 1994). The classical introduction to index theory usually requires some concepts from algebraic topology. For the purposes of this paper, this can be bypassed without much hindrance. Results in this section can be found in McLennan (2018, pp 245-265) and Pahl (2023).

Let $\mathbb{G}$ be a normal-form game with mixed strategy $\Sigma$. Given a neighborhood $O$ of $\Sigma$ suppose $f: O \rightarrow \Sigma$ is a differentiable map. Let $d_{f}$ be the displacement of $f$, i.e., $d_{f}(\sigma)=\sigma-f(\sigma)$. Then the fixed points of $f$ are the zeros of $d_{f}$. Suppose now that the Jacobian of $d_{f}$ at a zero $\sigma$ of $f$ is nonsingular. We assign the index +1 to $\sigma$ if the determinant of the Jacobian of $d_{f}$ is positive or -1 if such a determinant is negative. For the next definition, given a subset $\mathscr{O}$ of $\Sigma$, we denote by $\operatorname{cl}_{\Sigma}(\mathscr{O})$ the closure of $\mathscr{O}$ with respect to $\Sigma$.

Definition 2.2. An open neighborhood $\mathscr{O} \subset \Sigma$ of a component of equilibria (in mixed strategies) $K$ of normal-form game $\mathbb{G}$ is admissible if every equilibrium of $\mathbb{G}$ in $\mathrm{cl}_{\Sigma}(\mathscr{O})$ belongs to $K$.

When a finite game $\mathbb{G}$ has a component of equilibria $K$ that consists of more than a single strategy profile, we extend the definition of the index as follows. Take a continuous map $g_{\mathbb{G}}$ : $\Sigma \rightarrow \Sigma$ such that the fixed points of $g_{\mathbb{G}}$ are the Nash equilibria of game $\mathbb{G}$ and $g_{\mathbb{G}}$ continuously depends on the payoffs of $\mathbb{G}$. An example of such a map is the map Nash (1951) constructed to prove existence of equilibria in mixed strategies. Consider a neighborhood $O$ of $\Sigma$ and $r: O \rightarrow \Sigma$ a retraction to the closest point in $\Sigma$. Let $\mathscr{O} \subset O$ be an open neighborhood of $K$ in the affine space generated by $\Sigma$, whose closure contains no other fixed point of $g$. We approximate $\left(g_{\mathbb{G}} \circ r\right)$ uniformly by a differentiable function $f: O \rightarrow \Sigma$ without fixed points on the boundary of $\mathscr{O}$ and such that the displacement of $f$ at any fixed point has nonsingular Jacobian. For any sufficiently close approximation, the sum of the indexes of the (isolated) fixed points of $f$ in $\mathscr{O}$ is constant and can be taken as the definition of the index of the component $K .{ }^{9}$

We can now define the index with respect to the best-reply correspondence of game $\mathbb{G}$ following the same procedure as in GW. Consider now $\mathscr{O} \cap \Sigma$. For notational convenience, we will denote this intersection from now on as $\mathscr{O}$. Let $W$ be an open neighborhood of $\operatorname{Graph}\left(\mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}}\right)$ such that $W \cap\left\{(\sigma, \sigma) \in \Sigma \times \Sigma \mid \sigma \in \mathrm{cl}_{\Sigma}(\mathscr{O})-\mathscr{O}\right\}=\varnothing$. There exists $\bar{W} \subset W$ a neighborhood of $\operatorname{Graph}\left(\mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}}\right)$ such that any two continuous functions $f_{0}$ and $f_{1}$ from $\Sigma$ to $\Sigma$ whose graphs are in the neighborhood $\bar{W}$ are homotopic by a homotopy $H:[0,1] \times \Sigma \rightarrow \Sigma$ with

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{9}$ Under the continuous dependence of the payoffs of $\mathbb{G}$, this definition of index is independent of the particular map $g_{\mathbb{G}}$ used, it only depends on the game $\mathbb{G}$ (cf. DeMichelis and Germano (2000)).

Graph $(H(t, \cdot)) \subset \bar{W}$ for all $t \in[0,1]$ (cf. McLennan, 1989). Take a continuous map $f: \Sigma \rightarrow \Sigma$ with $\operatorname{Graph}(f) \subset \bar{W}$. We define the best-reply index of component $K$, denoted $\operatorname{Ind}_{\mathrm{BR}^{\mathrm{C}}}(K)$, as the fixed point index of the continuous map $\left.f\right|_{\mathscr{O}}: \mathscr{O} \rightarrow \Sigma$. The choice of the neighborhood $W$ and the homotopy property of the index (see Dold, 1972, Chapter VII, 5.15) imply that the index of the component is the same for any continuous map with graph in the neighborhood $\bar{W}$. We note that defining the index of a component from, say, the map that Nash used in (Nash, 1951) or from the best-reply correspondence are two distinct ways of defining the index, which can be shown to be equivalent (cf. GW). In addition, this process to define the index applies with insignificant changes if the correspondence between the simplices of strategies is contractible valued instead of convex valued (cf. McLennan, 1989). ${ }^{10}$ This fact will play an important role in Section 5.1, as we need to consider selections of a best-reply correspondence which are not necessarily convex-valued, but are contractible-valued.

One can generalize the definition of the best-reply index of a component of equilibria to the best-reply index of an admissible neighborhood, by using the exact same procedure as in the previous paragraph. This yields the index of a neighborhood by summing the indexes of the components of equilibria which are contained in it. For convenience, whenever we refer to the index of a component or an admissible neighborhood, it will be implicit that we refer to the best-reply index.

We are now ready to recall a few known properties of the index of equilibria which we will use in the proof of our main result. The proofs that the index satisfies such properties can be found in McLennan (2018) or GW.
I. 1 The index of an admissible neighborhood is locally constant with respect to payoff perturbations of the game. Formally, fix an admissible neighborhood $O$ in the mixed strategy set of a finite game $\mathbb{G}$. Then there exist $\bar{\delta}>0$, such that for any $0 \leq \delta \leq \bar{\delta}$ and a $\delta$-payoff-perturbation $\mathbb{G}^{\delta}$ of game $\mathbb{G}$, the index of $O$ (with respect to $\mathbb{G}^{\delta}$ ) is constant.
I. 2 The index of an equilibrium component is invariant to equivalent presentations of a game. If $K$ is a component of equilibria of $\mathbb{G}$ with index $c$, then for any equivalent game $\bar{G}$, the index of the equivalent component $\bar{K}$ is also $c$.
I. 3 The index of a component is invariant to the deletion of strictly inferior replies to the component. If $K$ is a component of equilibria with index $c$ of game $\mathbb{G}$, then deleting from the normal-form of game $\mathbb{G}$ the pure strategies of player $n$ which are strictly inferior replies to every profile in the component $K$ yields a new game $\mathbb{G}^{\prime}$ with the same component $K$ as an equilibrium component in $\mathbb{G}^{\prime}$ and with the same index $c$.
We also need three well-known properties of the index. For our purposes, we particularize their statements as follows:
I. 4 Multiplication: Let $\mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}}: \Sigma \Rightarrow \Sigma$ and $\mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}^{\prime}}: \Sigma^{\prime} \Rightarrow \Sigma^{\prime}$ be the best-reply correspondences of (respectively) games $\mathbb{G}$ and $\mathbb{G}^{\prime}$. Let $\mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}} \times \mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}^{\prime}}$ be the correspondence taking $(\sigma, \tau) \in$ $\Sigma \times \Sigma^{\prime}$ to $\mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}}(\sigma) \times \mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}^{\prime}}(\tau)$. If $O \times O^{\prime} \subset \Sigma \times \Sigma^{\prime}$ contains no fixed points of $\mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}} \times \mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}^{\prime}}$ in its boundary, then $O$ (respectively $O^{\prime}$ ) has no fixed points of $\mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}}$ (respectively $\mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}^{\prime}}$ ) in its boundary, and the index of $O \times O^{\prime}$ with respect to $\mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}} \times \mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}^{\prime}}$ is the multiplication of the indexes of $O$ (with respect to $\mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}}$ ) and of $O^{\prime}$ (with respect to $\mathrm{BR}^{\mathbb{G}^{\prime}}$ ).

[^0]

We conclude this section with the following result. In particular, it implies that if a component has zero index, then some ending node is reached with probability zero.

Proposition 2.3. If an equilibrium outcome $Q$ induced by a component of equilibria in mixed strategies $K$ has full support, then $K$ has non-zero index.

Proof. See Appendix A.

# 2.4. Main Result 

We recall the definition of Hyperstability.
Definition 2.4. A component $K$ of equilibria in mixed strategies of a normal-form game $\mathbb{G}$ is hyperstable if for each equivalent game $\tilde{\mathbb{G}}$ and every $\varepsilon>0$, there exists $\delta>0$ such that any $\delta$-payoff-perturbation $\tilde{\mathbb{G}}^{\delta}$ of $\tilde{\mathbb{G}}$ has an equilibrium which is $\varepsilon$-close to $\tilde{K}$ (the equivalent component in $\tilde{\mathbb{G}}$ to $K$ ).

Hyperstability is a property first formulated in Kohlberg and Mertens (1986) to refine Nash equilibria. It implies several desirable properties. ${ }^{11}$ In Section 5 we prove the following result.

Theorem 2.5. Fix a two-player game tree with perfect recall. Apart from a lower-dimensional, semi-algebraic set of payoffs, an equilibrium component is hyperstable if and only if it has non-zero index.

GW also offer a characterization of non-zero index Nash equilibrium components. However, their characterization requires a strengthening of hyperstability. Namely, GW show that a component has non-zero index if and only if it is uniformly hyperstable, that is, if for each $\varepsilon>0$, there exists $\delta>0$ such that for any equivalent game $\tilde{\mathbb{G}}$ and any $\delta$-perturbation $\tilde{\mathbb{G}}^{\delta}$, there exists an equilibrium of $\tilde{\mathbb{G}}^{\delta}$ which is within $\varepsilon$ of $\tilde{K}$ (the equivalent component of $\tilde{\mathbb{G}}$ ). Note that $\delta$ is fixed across all equivalent games, making uniform hyperstability a stronger concept than the combination of robustness to payoff perturbations and invariance. Nonetheless, our result implies that for generic two-player extensive-form games, a component is uniformly hyperstable if and only if it is hyperstable.

# 3. EXCLUDED GAMES 

The "Out"-component in the game in Figure 1 has player 1 excluding the subgame. In turn, behavior in the subgame as prescribed by such a component prevents player 1 from profiting by deviating and choosing In. In general, observed behavior crucially depends on the robustness of unobserved behavior. As we discussed in the Introduction, the reason the "Out"-component has zero index is that it specifies a set of strategy profiles in the subgame that, when analyzed relative to such a subgame, has itself zero index. In this section, we generalize this insight along with the notion of "excluded game" so that, given an equilibrium component, we can examine the interaction between the two players that occurs both on-path and off-path.

Take a two-player finite game tree with perfect recall $\Gamma$ and let $\mathscr{G}=\mathbb{R}^{2|Z|}$ be the space of payoffs over terminal nodes. For payoffs $G \in \mathscr{G}$, let $\mathbb{G}$ be the induced normal form. From now on, fix an equilibrium component $K$ that induces a unique outcome $Q \in \Delta(Z)$. Given the equilibrium component $K$, an information set $u$ is said to be on-path if $Q(u)>0$. Player $n$ 's collection of information sets that are on-path is $U_{n}^{+} \equiv\left\{u_{n} \in U_{n} \mid Q(u)>0\right\}$. Similarly, an information set is off-path if $Q(u)=0$. Player $n$ 's collection of information sets that are off-path of $Q$ is $U_{n}^{0} \equiv U_{n} \backslash U_{n}^{+}$.

Let $Z^{0}$ be the set of terminal nodes which have probability 0 under $Q$. We define

$$
S_{n}^{n} \equiv\left\{s_{n} \in S_{n} \mid \text { there exists } \sigma \in K \text { with } \mathbb{P}\left(Z^{0} \mid s_{n}, \sigma_{-n}\right)>0\right\}
$$

and call it player $n$ 's set of observable deviations. It consists of those player $n$ 's pure strategies in which, at some information set on-path according to $K$, player $n$ deviates and plays an action that has zero probability under $Q$. As usual, $\Sigma_{n}^{n} \equiv \Delta\left(S_{n}^{n}\right)$.

Let

$$
S_{n}^{+} \equiv\left\{s_{n}^{+}: U_{n}^{+} \rightarrow A_{n} \mid s_{n}^{+}(u) \in A_{n}(u) \text { for every } u \in U_{n}^{+}\right\}
$$

and $\Sigma_{n}^{+} \equiv \Delta\left(S_{n}^{+}\right)$. Note that these are not pure strategies because they assign choices only to on-path (of $K$ ) information sets.

The subset $S_{n}^{*} \subset S_{n}^{+}$is the collection of assignments of actions at on-path information sets that only assign actions that are taken in the equilibrium component $K$, that is

$$
S_{n}^{*} \equiv\left\{s_{n}^{*} \in S_{n}^{+} \mid Q\left(s_{n}^{*}(u)\right)>0 \text { for every } u \in U_{n}^{+}\right\}
$$

where the symbol $Q\left(s_{n}^{*}(u)\right)$ follows the notational convention established in section 2.2.
Define $\Sigma_{n}^{*} \equiv \Delta\left(S_{n}^{*}\right)$ and $\Sigma^{*} \equiv \Sigma_{1}^{*} \times \Sigma_{2}^{*}$. Analogously to (1), define also

$$
S_{n}^{0} \equiv\left\{s_{n}^{0}: U_{n}^{0} \rightarrow A_{n} \mid s_{n}^{0}(u) \in A_{n}(u) \text { for every } u \in U_{n}^{0}\right\}
$$

together with $\Sigma_{n}^{0} \equiv \Delta\left(S_{n}^{0}\right)$.
We will now split the mixed strategies of a player between an on- and off-path part. Given some player $n$ 's pure strategy $s_{n} \in S_{n}$ the restriction of $s_{n}$ to information sets in, respectively, $U_{n}^{+}$and $U_{n}^{0}$ is $q_{n}^{+}\left(s_{n}\right)$ and $q_{n}^{0}\left(s_{n}\right)$. These define maps $q_{n}^{+}: S_{n} \rightarrow S_{n}^{+}$and $q_{n}^{0}: S_{n} \rightarrow S_{n}^{0}$. Linear interpolation extends $q_{n}^{+}$to a map from $\Sigma_{n}$ to $\Sigma_{n}^{+}$. Analogously, $q_{n}^{0}$ is extended to a map from $\Sigma_{n}$ to $\Sigma_{n}^{0}$. Given a mixed strategy $\sigma_{n} \in \Sigma_{n}, q_{n}^{+}\left(\sigma_{n}\right)$ is, therefore, the marginal of $\sigma_{n}$ over $S_{n}^{+}$; and $q_{n}^{0}\left(\sigma_{n}\right)$ is the marginal of $\sigma_{n}$ over $S_{n}^{0}$. In particular, if $s_{n} \in S_{n} \backslash S_{n}^{n}$, then $s_{n}$ can be written

as a pair $\left(s_{n}^{*}, s_{n}^{0}\right) \in S_{n}^{*} \times S_{n}^{0}$ and we let $q_{n}^{*}\left(s_{n}\right)=s_{n}^{*}$. Similarly to above, $q_{n}^{*}: \Delta\left(S_{n} \backslash S_{n}^{n}\right) \rightarrow \Sigma_{n}^{*}$ is the affine map for which $q_{n}^{*}\left(\sigma_{n}^{*}\right)$ is the marginal of $\sigma_{n} \in \Delta\left(S_{n} \backslash S_{n}^{n}\right)$ over $\Sigma_{n}^{*}$. Let $q^{+} \equiv q_{1}^{+} \times q_{2}^{+}$, $q^{*} \equiv q_{1}^{*} \times q_{2}^{*}$, and $q^{0} \equiv q_{1}^{0} \times q_{2}^{0}$.

Given any pair $\left(\sigma_{n}^{+}, \sigma_{n}^{0}\right) \in \Sigma_{n}^{+} \times \Sigma_{n}^{0}$ let $\sigma_{n}^{+} * \sigma_{n}^{0}$ represent the product strategy $\sigma_{n}$ that satisfies $\sigma_{n}\left(s_{n}^{+}, s_{n}^{0}\right)=\sigma_{n}^{+}\left(s_{n}^{+}\right) \cdot \sigma_{n}^{0}\left(s_{n}^{0}\right)$ for every $s_{n}=\left(s_{n}^{+}, s_{n}^{0}\right)$.

If $\sigma_{n}$ is a product strategy then, by definition, there is a pair $\left(\sigma_{n}^{+}, \sigma_{n}^{0}\right) \in \Sigma_{n}^{+} \times \Sigma_{n}^{0}$ such that $\sigma_{n}=\sigma_{n}^{+} * \sigma_{n}^{0}$.

Obviously, not every mixed strategy is a product strategy over $S_{n}^{+} \times S_{n}^{0}$. Nonetheless, for any mixed strategy of a player there exists an outcome-equivalent product strategy. This observation is formalized below and follows directly from Kuhn's Theorem.

Lemma 3.1. For every $\sigma_{n} \in \Sigma_{n}$ there exists a pair $\left(\hat{\sigma}_{n}^{+}, \hat{\sigma}_{n}^{0}\right) \in \Sigma_{n}^{+} \times \Sigma_{n}^{0}$ such that, given any $\sigma_{-n} \in \Sigma_{-n}$, the strategy $\hat{\sigma}_{n}^{+} * \hat{\sigma}_{n}^{0}$ induces the same outcome as $\sigma_{n}$.

Definition 3.2 (Excluded game). Fix $\hat{\tau} \in K$ such that $\hat{\tau}_{n}=\hat{\tau}_{n}^{*} * \hat{\tau}_{n}^{0}$ with $\hat{\tau}_{n}^{*} \in \operatorname{int}\left(\Sigma_{n}^{*}\right)$, where the interior is relative to the affine space generated by $\Sigma_{n}^{*}$. Player $n$ 's excluded game is the normal-form game in which player $n$ 's strategy set is $S_{n}^{n}$, player $-n$ 's strategy set is $S_{-n}^{0}$ and the payoff function for player $m=1,2$ is defined for each profile $\left(s_{n}^{n}, s_{-n}^{0}\right) \in S_{n}^{n} \times S_{-n}^{0}$ as

$$
\mathbb{G}_{m}^{n}\left(s_{n}^{n}, s_{-n}^{0}\right) \equiv \sum_{s_{-n}^{n} \in S_{-n}^{n}} \hat{\tau}_{-n}^{\mathbb{B}}\left(s_{-n}^{\mathbb{B}}\right) \mathbb{G}_{m}\left(s_{n}^{n}, s_{-n}^{\mathbb{B}}, s_{-n}^{0}\right)
$$

Since the equilibrium component $K$ induces a unique probability distribution $Q$, the payoff function (3) does not depend on the particular choice of $\hat{\tau} \in K$, on the fact that $\hat{\tau}_{n}$ is a product (as $q_{n}^{*}\left(\hat{\tau}_{n}\right)$ can be used instead), or on the fact that $\hat{\tau}_{n}^{*}$ is chosen (for convenience) to be in the interior of $\Sigma_{n}^{*}$.

Remark 3.3. We note two particular cases. First, when no information set of player $-n$ is off-path in component $K$ then player $n$ 's excluded game is just a decision problem. Second, if $K$ is such that player $n$ does not have any observable deviation, as player 2 in the "Out"component of Figure 1, then we say that player $n$ does not have an excluded game. Also note that while in Figure 1 player 1's excluded game coincides with the proper subgame, in general, an excluded game is not necessarily a subgame.

Let $K_{-n}^{n}$ be the subset of player $-n$ 's mixed strategies in player $n$ 's excluded game such that player $n$ obtains a payoff that is no larger than what she obtains under the equilibrium component $K$ :

$$
K_{-n}^{n} \equiv\left\{\sigma_{-n}^{0} \in \Sigma_{-n}^{0} \mid \text { for all } s_{n}^{n} \in S_{n}^{n} \text { we have } \mathbb{G}_{n}^{n}\left(s_{n}^{n}, \sigma_{-n}^{0}\right) \leq G_{n}(Q)\right\}
$$

And let $\bar{\partial} K_{-n}^{n}$ be the subset of $K_{-n}^{n}$ where player $n$ has at least one deviation for which she is indifferent:

$$
\bar{\partial} K_{-n}^{n} \equiv\left\{\sigma_{-n}^{0} \in K_{-n}^{n} \mid \text { for some } s_{n}^{n} \in S_{n}^{n} \text { we have } \mathbb{G}_{n}^{n}\left(s_{n}^{n}, \sigma_{-n}^{0}\right)=G_{n}(Q)\right\}
$$

The set $\bar{\partial} K_{-n}^{n}$ contains the boundary of $K_{-n}^{n}$ relative to $\Sigma_{-n}^{0}$ but, in general, it is not equal to it. Player $n$ 's supporting polytope is $K^{n} \equiv \Sigma_{n}^{n} \times K_{-n}^{n}$. We also define $\bar{\partial} K^{n} \equiv \Sigma_{n}^{n} \times \bar{\partial} K_{-n}^{n}$. Later we show that under a generic choice of terminal payoffs for the game tree $K^{n}$ is a

full dimensional neighborhood in the strategy set of the excluded without equilibria in its boundary realtàive to this strategy set, thus admiting an index.

Example 3.4. In Figure 1, the supporting polytope $K^{1}$ to the "Out" component is $\Delta((L, R)) \times$ $\{\alpha \ell+(1-\alpha) r \mid 0 \leq \alpha \leq 2 / 3\}$.

Remark 3.5. Proposition 2.3 implies that if a zero-index component of equilibria in mixed strategies $K$ induces a unique outcome then such an outcome must not have full support. This result does not require any genericity assumption and it is a consequence of the twoplayer environment. Furthermore, assume that the component $K$ is such that for both $n=1,2$ we have $\bar{\partial} K^{n}=\varnothing$. Then every strategy $s_{n}^{n} \in S_{n}^{n}$ pays strictly less than $G_{n}(Q)$ against any equilibrium strategy of player $-n$. Hence, we can eliminate the deviations $s_{n}^{n}$ from $\mathbb{G}$ for both players leaving the index of component $K$ invariant (cf. Property I.3). The resulting game obtained after this elimination has an extensive-form where the outcome $Q$ induced by $K$ is completely mixed. Proposition 2.3 then implies that $K$ has non-zero index. Therefore, any zero-index equilibrium component $K$ is such that $\bar{\partial} K^{n} \neq \varnothing$ for some $n=1,2$.

Definition 3.6 (Included game). The included game $\mathbb{G}^{\circledR}$ associated with component $K$ is the normal-form game in which player $n$ 's strategy set is $S_{n}^{\circledR}$ and payoff functions for player $m=1,2$ are given by:

$$
\mathbb{G}_{m}^{\circledR}\left(s_{n}^{\circledR}, s_{-n}^{\circledR}\right) \equiv \mathbb{G}_{m}\left(s_{n}, s_{-n}\right)
$$

where $\left(s_{n}, s_{-n}\right) \in\left(q_{n}^{\circledR} \times q_{-n}^{\circledR}\right)^{-1}\left(s_{n}^{\circledR}, s_{-n}^{\circledR}\right)$.
Note that the payoffs in $\mathbb{G}^{\circledR}$ are well-defined since they do not depend on the particular choice of $\left(s_{n}, s_{-n}\right) \in\left(q_{n}^{\circledR} \times q_{-n}^{\circledR}\right)^{-1}\left(s_{n}^{\circledR}, s_{-n}^{\circledR}\right)$.

# 4. GENERICITY ASSUMPTIONS 

In Section 5 we fix a game $G$ with game tree $\Gamma$ and a zero-index component $K$ and prove that $K$ is not hyperstable provided it satisfies the following two assumptions:
A. 1 The outcome associated to $K$ is unique. Moreover, after eliminating all branches and nodes from $\Gamma$ which have zero probability under the equilibrium outcome induced by $K$, the set $q^{\circledR}(K)$ is a component of equilibria of $G^{\circledR}$.
A. 2 If $K$ induces a unique outcome in which player $n \in\{1,2\}$ has an excluded game, $K^{n}$ is a full-dimensional polytope in $\Sigma^{n}$ and every equilibrium payoff of $\mathbb{G}^{n}$ to player $n$ in $K^{n}$ is strictly lower than player $n$ 's equilibrium payoff induced by $K$.
Assumption A. 1 is a standard property of generic extensive-form games (see Kreps and Wilson, 1982 or Govindan and Wilson, 2001). For our purposes, note that the definition of excluded game relies on the component inducing a unique outcome. The new assumption is A.2. The statement concerning the full-dimensionality of polytope $K^{n}$ in $\Sigma^{n}$ is satisfied generically. ${ }^{12}$ Assumption A. 2 as a whole tells us that $K^{n}$ is the closure of an admissible

This guarantees full-dimensionality of $K^{n}$.

The next example shows that A. 1 does not imply A.2.
Example 4.1. Consider the game in Figure 4.
The game has two equilibrium outcomes, each of which is associated to two different equilibrium components. In the first one, player 1 plays $T$ and player 2 plays $\ell a$. In the second, player 1 plays $B$ and player 2 plays $r a$. This game satisfies A. 1 but does not satisfy A.2. Recall that in the excluded game $\mathbb{G}^{1}$ of player 1 associated to the first component, the non-deviating player 2 plays, at all information sets which are on equilibrium-path the exact equilibrium distribution - therefore, player 2 must play $\ell$ in the leftmost information set. In this excluded game, the deviating player 1 is a dummy player (she only has one strategy $S_{1}^{1}=(B)$ ) and player 2 has two strategies (i.e., $S_{2}^{1}=\{\ell a, \ell b\}$ ).

If player 2 plays $\ell a$, the payoff in the excluded game is $(1,1)$, and if player 2 plays $\ell b$, the payoff is $(3 / 2,0)$. Therefore, $(B, \ell a)$ is the obvious equilibrium of the excluded game $\mathbb{G}^{1}$, which gives player 1 the equilibrium payoff of the component, violating A.2.

The next proposition implies that restricting to games that satisfy Assumptions A. 1 and A. 2 is a mild constraint.

Definition 4.2. A subset $\mathscr{G}^{\prime} \subseteq \mathscr{G}$ is generic if its complement is a lower-dimensional semialgebraic set.

Proposition 4.3. The subset $\mathscr{G}^{\prime} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{N|Z|}$ for which properties A. 1 and A. 2 are satisfied is generic.

Proof. It is well-known that Assumption A. 1 is generic in the space of extensive-form games (Kreps and Wilson, 1982; Govindan and Wilson, 2001). The proof that generic two-player games satisfy Assumption A. 2 is relegated to Appendix B.

# 5. Proof of Theorem 2.5 

It is already known that a non-zero index component is hyperstable. It can be proved by observing that equivalent components have the same index and that a component with non-zero index is robust to sufficiently small payoff perturbations.

${ }^{13}$ Henceforth, we focus on showing that a hyperstable component must have non-zero index.

The strategy of the proof is to show that if component $K$ has zero index then $K$ is not hyperstable. Thus, we need to find a game $\mathbb{G}$ equivalent to $\mathbb{G}$ and a neighborhood $\bar{V}$ of $\bar{K}$ (the component in $\mathbb{G}$ equivalent to $K$ ) such that for any $\varepsilon>0$, there is an $\varepsilon$-payoff-perturbation $\overline{\mathbb{G}}^{\varepsilon}$ of $\mathbb{G}$ with no equilibrium in $\bar{V}$. We proceed in three steps. In Step 1, we modify the original game $\mathbb{G}$ to an auxiliary game to show that for some $n=1,2$, the supporting polytope $K^{n}$ has zero index in the excluded game $\mathbb{G}^{n}$. In Step 2, we construct a game equivalent to $\mathbb{G}^{n}$ and a perturbation so that the perturbed game does not have an equilibrium in the subset of the strategy profiles equivalent to $K^{n}$. This is used in Step 3 to construct a game equivalent to the original game $\mathbb{G}$ and a perturbation that shows that the original zero index component $K$ is not hyperstable. Prior to each step we present the key conceptual details about the step and overall strategy of the argument.

# 5.1. Step 1: For some player $n$, the supporting polytope has index 0 in $\mathbb{G}^{n}$ 

From Proposition 2.3 we know that at least one player has an excluded game. We proceed under the assumption that both players have an excluded game as the proof can be easily adapted to the case in which only one has it. Observe that $K^{n}$ is full-dimensional in $\Sigma^{n}$ and admissible with respect to $\mathbb{G}^{n}$ (cf. A.2). Therefore, it has a well-defined index in $\mathbb{G}^{n}$. We also assume that for each player $n=1,2$ the supporting polytope $K^{n}$ contains an equilibrium of $\mathbb{G}^{n}$. If for some $n=1,2$ the excluded game $\mathbb{G}^{n}$ does not have an equilibrium in $K^{n}$ then such a supporting polytope has index 0 and we can move to Section 5.2.

We now prove that there exists $n=1,2$ such that $K^{n}$ has index 0 in $\mathbb{G}^{n}$. The objective is to use the multiplication property of the index (cf. I.4) to express the index of $K$ as the product of the indexes of $K^{1}$ and $K^{2}$ in their corresponding excluded games so that if the index of $K$ is zero then either the index of $K^{1}$ or the index of $K^{2}$ is zero as well. With that in mind, we perturb the original game so that each player is forced to play an observable deviation (i.e. an element of the strategy set in their excluded games) with vanishing probability. We then show that the non-deviating player can effectively best-reply by separately responding to the event in which the other player is forced to play as in her excluded game, and to the event in which the other player plays according to the equilibrium path defined by the component $K$. This defines a selection of the best-reply that, after some manipulations invoking the properties of the index, can be expressed as a product of the best replies in $\mathbb{G}^{*}, \mathbb{G}^{1}$, and $\mathbb{G}^{2}$.

Let us define the auxiliary extensive-form game $G^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ in Figure 5. First, Nature randomizes between three states, $\theta_{0}$ with probability $1-\varepsilon_{1}-\varepsilon_{2}, \theta_{1}$ with probability $\varepsilon_{1}$, and $\theta_{2}$ with probability $\varepsilon_{2}$. For each $n=1,2$, player $n$ observes if Nature has selected $\theta_{n}$ but cannot distinguish between $\theta_{0}$ and $\theta_{-n}$. If Nature chooses $\theta_{n}$ then player $n$ chooses a member of $S_{n}^{n}$. In turn, if Nature chooses either $\theta_{0}$ or $\theta_{-n}$ then player $n$, without observing player $-n$ 's move, chooses an element from $S_{n}$. Payoffs are inherited from the original game $\mathbb{G}$.

Nature, by choosing $\theta_{n}$, forces player $n$ to play from the same strategy set as in her excluded game. Nonetheless, players have their entire strategy set available after $\theta_{0}$. Note that game $G^{0,0}$ is equivalent to the original game $\mathbb{G}$. We denote the component equivalent to

Lemma 5.1. For $\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}>0$ sufficiently small, every equilibrium $\left(\tau_{1}, \zeta_{1}^{1}, \tau_{2}, \zeta_{2}^{2}\right) \in \mathscr{O}^{0,0}$ of game $G^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ satisfies $\operatorname{Supp}\left(\tau_{n}\right) \cap S_{n}^{n}=\varnothing$ for each $n=1,2$. Passing to subsequences if necessary, we can assume that the sequence of strategy profiles converges to $\left(\tau_{1}, \zeta_{1}^{1}, \tau_{2}, \zeta_{2}^{2}\right)$. In addition, writing $\tau_{1}^{k}=(1-$ $\left.\alpha_{k}\right) \tau_{1}^{\times, k}+\alpha_{k} \tau_{1}^{1, k}$, with $\alpha_{k} \geq 0, \operatorname{Supp}\left(\tau_{1}^{\times, k}\right) \subseteq\left(S_{1} \backslash S_{1}^{1}\right)$ and $\operatorname{Supp}\left(\tau_{1}^{1, k}\right) \subseteq S_{1}^{1}$, we also assume $\psi^{k} \equiv \varepsilon_{1}^{k}\left[\varepsilon_{1}^{k}+\left(1-\varepsilon_{1}^{k}\right) \alpha_{k}\right]^{-1} \rightarrow \psi \in[0,1]$. Observe that the support of $\tau_{2}$ is a subset of $\left(S_{2} \backslash S_{2}^{2}\right)$, since $\left(\tau_{1}, \zeta_{1}^{1}, \tau_{2}, \zeta_{2}^{2}\right) \in K^{0,0}$.
Claim 5.2. Suppose $\operatorname{Supp}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}\right) \subseteq\left(S_{2} \backslash S_{2}^{2}\right)$. If $q_{2}^{*}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}\right)$ is equivalent to $q_{2}^{*}\left(\tau_{2}\right)$ in $\mathbb{G}^{*}$, then for $n=1,2$ we have $\mathbb{G}_{n}\left(\tau_{1}^{\times, k}, \bar{\tau}_{2}\right)=\mathbb{G}_{n}\left(\tau_{1}^{\times, k}, \tau_{2}\right)$.
Proof of Claim 5.2. Note that $\left(\tau_{1}^{k}, \tau_{2}^{k}\right) \rightarrow\left(\tau_{1}, \tau_{2}\right) \in K$ so that $\operatorname{Supp}\left(\tau_{2}\right) \cap S_{2}^{2}=\varnothing$. Since $q_{2}^{*}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}\right)$ is equivalent to $q_{2}^{*}\left(\tau_{2}\right)$ in $\mathbb{G}^{*}$ both $q_{2}^{*}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}\right)$ and $q_{2}^{*}\left(\tau_{2}\right)$ give the same payoff against any player 1's strategy $\tau_{1}^{*}$ in $\mathbb{G}^{*}$. Given $\tau_{1}^{\times, k} \in \Delta\left(S_{1} \backslash S_{1}^{1}\right)$, both $q_{2}^{*}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}\right)$ and $q_{2}^{*}\left(\tau_{2}\right)$ yield the same payoff against $q_{1}^{*}\left(\tau_{1}^{\times, k}\right)$. Therefore, $\mathbb{G}_{n}\left(\tau_{1}^{\times, k}, \bar{\tau}_{2}\right)=\mathbb{G}_{n}^{*}\left(q^{*}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}\right), q_{1}^{*}\left(\tau_{1}^{\times, k}\right)\right)=\mathbb{G}_{n}^{*}\left(q^{*}\left(\tau_{2}\right), q_{1}^{*}\left(\tau_{1}^{\times, k}\right)\right)=$ $\mathbb{G}_{n}\left(\tau_{1}^{\times, k}, \tau_{2}\right)$.

For $k$ sufficiently large, $\operatorname{Supp}\left(\tau_{2}\right) \subseteq \operatorname{Supp}\left(\tau_{2}^{k}\right)$. For such a $k$, the limit $\tau_{2}$ maximizes player 2's expected payoff at her information set following $\theta_{0}$ and $\theta_{1}$. For $x_{2} \in \Sigma_{2}$, player 2's expected payoff is
(4) $\left[\varepsilon_{1}^{k}+\left(1-\varepsilon_{1}^{k}-\varepsilon_{2}^{k}\right) \alpha_{k}\right]\left\{\psi^{k} \mathbb{G}_{2}\left(\zeta_{1}^{1, k}, x_{2}\right)+\left(1-\psi^{k}\right) \mathbb{G}_{2}\left(\tau_{1}^{1, k}, x_{2}\right)\right]+\left(1-\varepsilon_{1}^{k}-\varepsilon_{2}^{k}\right)\left(1-\alpha_{k}\right)\left\{\mathbb{G}_{2}\left(\tau_{1}^{\times, k}, x_{2}\right)\right\}$.

Let $A_{2} \subset \Sigma_{2}$ be defined as: $\bar{\tau}_{2} \in A_{2}$ if and only if $q_{2}^{\#}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}\right)$ is equivalent to $q_{2}^{\#}\left(\tau_{2}\right)$ in $\mathbb{G}^{\#}$. Since $\tau_{2}$ maximizes expression (4), Claim 5.2 implies that $\tau_{2}$ also solves

$$
\max _{x_{2} \in A_{2}} \psi^{k} \mathbb{G}_{2}\left(\zeta_{1}^{1, k}, x_{2}\right)+\left(1-\psi^{k}\right) \mathbb{G}_{2}\left(\tau_{1}^{1, k}, x_{2}\right)
$$

From Lemma 3.1, player 2 has a product strategy $\tau_{2}^{\#} * \tau_{2}^{0}$ that is equivalent to $\tau_{2}$ in $\mathbb{G}$. Since $\left(\tau_{1}, \tau_{2}\right) \in K$, then $\tau_{2}^{\#}$ is equivalent to $\bar{\tau}_{2}^{\#}$ in $\mathbb{G}^{\#}$. By the definition of payoff functions in player 1's excluded game, $\tau_{2}^{0}$ solves

$$
\max _{x_{2}^{0} \in \Sigma_{2}^{0}} \psi^{k} \mathbb{G}_{2}^{1}\left(\zeta_{1}^{1, k}, x_{2}^{0}\right)+\left(1-\psi^{k}\right) \mathbb{G}_{2}^{1}\left(\tau_{1}^{1, k}, x_{2}^{0}\right)
$$

That is, for $k$ large enough, $\tau_{2}^{0}$ is a best-reply against $\psi^{k} \zeta_{1}^{1, k}+\left(1-\psi^{k}\right) \tau_{1}^{1, k}$ in player 1's excluded game $\mathbb{G}^{1}$. Of course, $\tau_{2}^{0}$ is also a best-reply against the limit $\psi \zeta_{1}^{1}+(1-\psi) \tau_{1}^{1}$.

In turn, $\zeta_{1}^{1, k}$ is a best-reply (when player 1's strategy is constrained to $\Sigma_{1}^{1}$ ) against $\tau_{2}^{k}$ in $\mathbb{G}$ for every $k$. By continuity, $\zeta_{1}^{1}$ is a constrained best-reply against $\tau_{2}$ in $\mathbb{G}$ and, therefore, also against the equivalent product strategy $\tau_{2}^{\#} * \tau_{2}^{0}$, which implies that $\zeta_{1}^{1}$ is a best-reply against $\tau_{2}^{0}$ in $\mathbb{G}^{1}$. Using an analogous argument, if $\alpha_{k}>0$ for all $k$, we also conclude that $\tau_{1}^{1}$ is a best-reply against $\tau_{2}^{0}$ in $\mathbb{G}^{1}$. If we do not have $\alpha_{k}>0$ for all $k$ then either there exists a subsequence for which it holds or $\psi=1$. In either case, $\left(\tau_{2}^{0}, \psi \zeta_{1}^{1}+(1-\psi) \tau_{1}^{1}\right)$ is an equilibrium of $\mathbb{G}^{1}$.

From genericity property A.2, no equilibrium of $\mathbb{G}^{1}$ gives the same payoff as the equilibrium outcome $Q$ to player 1. Therefore, $\tau_{2}^{0} \notin \bar{\partial} K_{2}$ and, for every $s_{1}^{1} \in S_{1}^{1}$ we have $\mathbb{G}_{1}\left(s_{1}^{1}, \tau_{2}\right)=$ $\mathbb{G}_{1}^{1}\left(s_{1}^{1}, \tau_{2}^{0}\right)<G_{1}(Q)$. We conclude that for sufficiently large $k$, every member of $S_{1}^{1}$ is a strictly inferior reply to $\tau_{2}^{k}$. So for $k$ large enough, $\operatorname{Supp}\left(\tau_{1}^{k}\right) \subseteq S_{1} \backslash S_{1}^{1}$ which finishes the proof of the first case.

For the second case, consider positive sequences $\left(\varepsilon_{i}^{k}\right)_{k}, i=1,2$ converging to 0 and $\left(\sigma^{k}\right)_{k \in \mathbb{N}} \subset$ $\mathscr{O}^{0,0}$ a sequence of equilibria of $G^{\varepsilon^{k_{1}}, \varepsilon_{2}^{k}}$. For sufficiently large $k$, using an argument symmetric to the first case, $\operatorname{Supp}\left(\tau_{2}^{k}\right) \subseteq\left(S_{2} \backslash S_{2}^{2}\right)$ and $S_{2}^{2}$ is a set of strictly inferior replies after $\theta_{0}$ to $\tau_{1}^{k}$. From these two cases, for sufficiently small $\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}>0$, Lemma 5.1 follows.

Take $\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}>0$ as small as prescribed by Lemma 5.1. Every equilibrium of $G^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ in $\mathscr{O}^{0,0}$ is such that any strategy that assigns positive probability to some member of $S_{n}^{n}$ after $\theta_{0}$ is a strictly inferior reply to the equilibrium. With abuse of notation, denote also by $G^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ the game that is obtained by eliminating $S_{1}^{1}$ and $S_{2}^{2}$ from players' actions at their information set after $\theta_{0}$. Since they are always inferior replies, their elimination does not affect the index of $\mathscr{O}^{0,0}$.

For $\delta>0$, define

$$
U_{n}^{\delta} \equiv\left\{\tau_{n} \in \Delta\left(S_{n} \backslash S_{n}^{n}\right) \mid \mathbb{G}_{-n}\left(s_{-n}^{-n}, \tau_{n}\right)<G_{-n}(Q)-\delta \text { for all } s_{-n}^{-n} \in S_{-n}^{-n}\right\}
$$

Since the component $K$ induces a unique distribution $Q$, the component that induces $Q$ in $\mathbb{G}^{*}$ is a rectangle $R_{1} \times R_{2}$ with $R_{n} \subseteq \Sigma_{n}^{*}$. ${ }^{14}$ From this we obtain a $\delta$-neighborhood $B_{n}^{\delta} \subseteq \Sigma_{n}^{*}$ of $R_{n}$ such that $B^{\delta} \equiv B_{1}^{\delta} \times B_{2}^{\delta}$ is a neighborhood of $R_{1} \times R_{2}$ and does not contain any other equilibrium of $\mathbb{G}^{*}$. Let $V_{1}^{\delta} \equiv\left(q_{1}^{*}\right)^{-1}\left(B_{1}^{\delta}\right), V_{2}^{\delta} \equiv\left(q_{2}^{*}\right)^{-1}\left(B_{2}^{\delta}\right)$, and $V^{\delta} \equiv V_{1}^{\delta} \times V_{2}^{\delta}$. Fix in addition $\delta>0$ sufficiently small such that for both $n=1,2$ all equilibria of player $n$ 's excluded game in $K^{n}$ induce a payoff smaller than $G_{n}(Q)-\delta$ (such $\delta>0$ exists due to Assumption A.2).

Claim 5.3. For $\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}>0$ sufficiently small,
(1) $\mathscr{O}^{\delta} \equiv\left(\left[V_{1}^{\delta} \cap U_{1}^{\delta}\right] \times \Sigma_{1}^{1}\right) \times\left(\left[V_{2}^{\delta} \cap U_{2}^{\delta}\right] \times \Sigma_{2}^{2}\right)$ is admissible for $G^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$;
(2) The symmetric difference $\mathscr{O}^{\delta} \Delta \mathscr{O}^{0,0}$ contains no equilibrium of $G^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$.

Proof. We start by proving admissibility of $\mathscr{O}^{\delta}$ for $G^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$. Let $\left(\varepsilon_{n}^{k}\right)_{\delta \in \mathbb{N}}$ converge to 0 for $n=1,2$ such that $\left(\zeta^{k}, \tau^{k}\right)$ is an equilibrium of $G^{\varepsilon_{1}^{k}, \varepsilon_{2}^{k}}$ in $\mathrm{cl}\left(\mathscr{O}^{\delta}\right)$, where the closure is taken with respect to $\left(\times_{n=1,2} \Delta\left(S_{n} \backslash S_{n}^{n}\right) \times \Sigma_{1}^{1} \times \Sigma_{2}^{2}\right)$. Consider a limit $(\zeta, \tau)$. By A.1, $q^{*}(\tau)$ is an equilibrium of $\mathbb{G}^{*}$ that induces $Q$. Therefore, for $k$ large enough, $q^{*}\left(\tau^{k}\right) \in B^{\delta}$, which implies $\tau^{k} \in V^{\delta}$. Recall that $\tau_{n} \in \Delta\left(S_{n} \backslash S_{n}^{n}\right)$ and take a product strategy $\tau_{n}^{*} * \tau_{n}^{0}$ equivalent to $\tau_{n}$ in $\mathbb{G}$. We claim that $\left(\zeta_{-n}^{-n}, \tau_{n}^{0}\right)$ is an equilibrium of the excluded game $\mathbb{G}^{-n}$. It is clear that $\zeta_{-n}^{-n}$ is a best-reply of player $-n$ against $\tau_{n}^{0}$ in $\mathbb{G}^{-n}$. It remains to show that $\tau_{n}^{0}$ is a best-reply of player $n$ against $\zeta_{-n}^{-n}$ in $\mathbb{G}^{-n}$. Since $\tau_{n}^{k}$ is an equilibrium strategy in $G^{\varepsilon_{1}^{k}, \varepsilon_{2}^{k}}$, it solves

$$
\max _{x_{n} \in \Delta\left(S_{n} \backslash S_{n}^{n}\right)} \varepsilon_{-n}^{k} \mathbb{G}_{n}\left(x_{n}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n, k}\right)+\left(1-\varepsilon_{1}^{k}-\varepsilon_{2}^{k}\right) \mathbb{G}_{n}\left(x_{n}, \tau_{-n}^{k}\right)
$$

For $k$ sufficiently large, $\operatorname{Supp}\left(\tau_{n}\right) \subseteq \operatorname{Supp}\left(\tau_{n}^{k}\right)$, so $\tau_{n}$ is also a solution to (5). Note that for every $x_{n} \in \Delta\left(S_{n} \backslash S_{n}^{n}\right)$ we have $\mathbb{G}_{n}\left(x_{n}, \tau_{-n}^{k}\right)=\mathbb{G}_{n}^{*}\left(q_{n}^{*}\left(x_{n}\right), q_{-n}^{*}\left(\tau_{-n}^{k}\right)\right)$. Therefore, since $\tau_{n}^{*}$ is equivalent to $\dot{\tau}_{n}^{*}$ in $\mathbb{G}^{*}$, we obtain $\mathbb{G}_{n}\left(\tau_{n}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n, k}\right)=\mathbb{G}_{n}^{-n}\left(\tau_{n}^{0}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n, k}\right)$. Taking limits in $k$, we obtain that $\tau_{n}^{0}$ is a best-reply against $\zeta_{-n}^{-n}$ in $\mathbb{G}^{-n}$. That is, $\left(\tau_{n}^{0}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)$ is an equilibrium of $\mathbb{G}^{-n}$ as claimed. This implies $\mathbb{G}_{-n}^{-n}\left(\tau_{n}^{0}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)<\mathbb{G}_{-n}(Q)-\delta$, by Assumption A. 2 and our choice of $\delta$. Hence, $\mathbb{G}_{-n}\left(\tau_{n}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)=\mathbb{G}_{-n}^{-n}\left(\tau_{n}^{0}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)<\mathbb{G}_{-n}(Q)-\delta$. That is, $\tau_{n}^{k} \in U_{n}^{\delta}$ for sufficiently large $k$. This proves that for $\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}>0$ small enough $\mathscr{O}^{\delta}$ is admissible for $G^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$.

We now prove that for sufficiently small $\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}>0, \mathscr{O}^{\delta}$ contains the equilibria of $G^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ that are contained in $\mathscr{O}^{0,0}$. It is sufficient to prove that for any convergent sequence $\left(\zeta^{k}, \tau^{k}\right)_{k \in \mathbb{N}} \subset$ $\mathscr{O}^{0,0}$ of equilibria $G^{\varepsilon_{1}^{k}, \varepsilon_{2}^{k}}$ with limit $(\zeta, \tau)$ and $\varepsilon_{n}^{k}$ converging to 0 for $n=1,2$, the sequence is eventually in $\mathscr{O}^{\delta}$. First observe that the limit must satisfy $\mathbb{G}_{-n}\left(\zeta_{-n}^{-n}, \tau_{n}\right) \leq G_{-n}(Q)$. Take a product strategy $\tau_{n}^{*} * \tau_{n}^{0}$ equivalent to $\tau_{n}$ in $\mathbb{G}$. We claim that $\left(\zeta_{-n}^{-n}, \tau_{n}^{0}\right)$ is an equilibrium of the excluded game $\mathbb{G}^{-n}$. It is clear that $\zeta_{-n}^{-n}$ is a best-reply of player $-n$ against $\tau_{n}^{0}$ in $\mathbb{G}^{-n}$. It remains to show that $\tau_{n}^{0}$ is a best-reply of player $n$ against $\zeta_{-n}^{-n}$ in $\mathbb{G}^{-n}$. Since $\tau_{n}^{k}$ is an equilibrium strategy in $G^{\varepsilon_{1}^{k}, \varepsilon_{2}^{k}}$, it solves (5). Continuing the argument in the same fashion as in the first part, we obtain that $\left(\tau_{n}^{0}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)$ is an equilibrium of $\mathbb{G}^{-n}$. This implies

$\mathbb{G}_{-n}^{-n}\left(\tau_{n}^{0}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)<\mathbb{G}_{-n}(Q)-\delta$, by Assumption A. 2 and our choice of $\delta$. Hence, $\mathbb{G}_{-n}\left(\tau_{n}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)=$ $\mathbb{G}_{-n}^{-n}\left(\tau_{n}^{0}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)<\mathbb{G}_{-n}(Q)-\delta$. Thus $\left(\zeta^{k}, \tau^{k}\right)$ belongs to $\mathscr{O}^{\delta}$ for sufficiently large $k$.

The proof of the result that for sufficiently small $\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}>0, \mathscr{O}^{0,0}$ contains the equilibria of $G^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ that are contained in $\mathscr{O}^{\delta}$ can be obtained from noticing that any limit $(\zeta, \tau)$ of a sequence of equilibria in $\mathscr{O}^{\delta}$ satisfies $\tau \in V^{\delta}$ and $\tau \in U^{\delta}$.

We now construct an expression for the index of $\mathscr{O}^{\delta}$ that allows us to conclude that for some $n=1,2$, the supporting polytope $K^{n}$ has zero index with respect to $\mathbb{G}^{n}$. When player $n$ best-replies against $\left(\tau_{-n}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)$ in game $G^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ at her information set after $\theta_{0}$, player $n$ chooses $\tau_{n} \in \Delta\left(S_{n} \backslash S_{n}^{n}\right)$ that maximizes

$$
\varepsilon_{-n} \mathbb{G}_{n}\left(\tau_{n}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)+\left(1-\varepsilon_{1}-\varepsilon_{2}\right) \mathbb{G}_{n}\left(\tau_{n}, \tau_{-n}\right)
$$

Since actions in $S_{n}^{n}, n=1,2$ are no longer available after $\theta_{0}$, the function $\mathbb{G}_{n}\left(\tau_{n}, \tau_{-n}\right)$ only depends on $q_{n}^{\#}\left(\tau_{n}\right)$ and $q_{-n}^{\#}\left(\tau_{-n}\right)$. In order to compute the best-reply $\tau_{n}$, player $n$ only requires $\zeta_{-n}^{-n}$ and $\tau_{-n}^{\#}$. The correspondence that assigns to each $\left(\zeta_{-n}^{-n}, \tau_{-n}^{\#}\right)$ the optimal $\tau_{n} \in \Delta\left(S_{n} \backslash S_{n}^{n}\right)$ is

$$
\mathrm{BR}_{n}^{\#, \varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}: \Sigma_{-n}^{-n} \times \Sigma_{-n}^{\#} \Rightarrow \Delta\left(S_{n} \backslash S_{n}^{n}\right)
$$

In addition, define the correspondence $\mathrm{BR}_{n}^{\times}: \Delta\left(S_{-n} \backslash S_{-n}^{-n}\right) \Rightarrow \Sigma_{n}^{n}$ by:

$$
\mathrm{BR}_{n}^{\times}\left(\tau_{-n}\right) \equiv \arg \max _{\zeta_{n}^{0} \in \Delta\left(S_{n}^{n}\right)} \mathbb{G}_{n}\left(\tau_{-n}, \zeta_{n}^{n}\right)
$$

Define $\mathrm{BR}^{\times} \equiv \mathrm{BR}_{1}^{\times} \times \mathrm{BR}_{2}^{\times}$. Let $\mathrm{id}_{n}$ be the identity in $\Sigma_{n}^{n}$. Player $n$ 's best-reply correspondence $\mathrm{BR}_{n}^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ in game $G^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ is

$$
\mathrm{BR}_{n}^{\times} \times\left[\mathrm{BR}_{n}^{\#, \varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}} \circ\left(\mathrm{id}_{-n} \times q_{-n}^{\#}\right)\right]: \Sigma_{-n}^{-n} \times \Delta\left(S_{-n} \backslash S_{-n}^{-n}\right) \Rightarrow \Sigma_{n}^{n} \times \Delta\left(S_{n} \backslash S_{n}^{n}\right)
$$

And the best-reply correspondence in $G^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ is $\mathrm{BR}^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}} \equiv \mathrm{BR}_{1}^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}} \times \mathrm{BR}_{2}^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$.
Instead of using $\mathrm{BR}^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ directly to compute the index of $\mathscr{O}^{\delta}$ we use a selection of $\mathrm{BR}^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$. That is, a new correspondence whose graph is a subset of the graph of $\mathrm{BR}^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$. To define it, consider first the correspondence $\phi_{n}^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}: \Sigma_{-n}^{-n} \times \Sigma_{-n}^{\#} \Rightarrow \Sigma_{n}^{\#} \times \Sigma_{n}^{0}$ that assigns to each $\left(\zeta_{-n}^{-n}, \tau_{-n}^{\#}\right) \in$ $\Sigma_{-n}^{-n} \times \Sigma_{-n}^{\#}$ the set of pairs $\left(\tau_{n}^{\#}, \tau_{n}^{0}\right) \in \Sigma_{n}^{\#} \times \Sigma_{n}^{0}$ that satisfy

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \tau_{n}^{\#} \in q_{n}^{\#} \circ \mathrm{BR}_{n}^{\#, \varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}\left(\zeta_{-n}^{-n}, \tau_{-n}^{\#}\right), \text { and } \\
& \tau_{n}^{0} \in \arg \max _{\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{0} \in \Sigma_{n}^{0}} \mathbb{G}_{n}\left(\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{\#} * \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{0}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $e_{n}: \Sigma_{n}^{\#} \times \Sigma_{n}^{0} \rightarrow \Delta\left(S_{n} \backslash S_{n}^{n}\right)$ be defined by $e_{n}\left(\tau_{n}^{\#}, \tau_{n}^{0}\right) \equiv \tau_{n}^{\#} * \tau_{n}^{0}$. Define also $w_{n}: \Sigma_{n}^{n} \times \Delta\left(S_{n}\right.$ $\left.S_{n}^{n}\right) \rightarrow \Sigma_{n}^{n} \times \Sigma_{n}^{\#} \times \Sigma_{n}^{0}$ by $w_{n}\left(\zeta_{n}^{n}, \tau_{n}\right) \equiv\left(\zeta_{n}^{n}, q_{n}^{\#}\left(\tau_{n}\right), q_{n}^{0}\left(\tau_{n}\right)\right)$. As usual, $e \equiv e_{1} \times e_{2}, w \equiv w_{1} \times w_{2}$, and $\phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}} \equiv \phi_{1}^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}} \times \phi_{2}^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$. Consider the correspondence

$$
\Phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}} \equiv\left(e \circ \phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}} \circ w\right): \Sigma_{1}^{1} \times \Sigma_{2}^{2} \times \Delta\left(S_{1} \backslash S_{1}^{1}\right) \times \Delta\left(S_{2} \backslash S_{2}^{2}\right) \Rightarrow \Delta\left(S_{1} \backslash S_{1}^{1}\right) \times \Delta\left(S_{2} \backslash S_{2}^{2}\right)
$$

Lemma 5.4. $\Phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ is a nonempty, contractible, and compact valued, upper hemicontinuous correspondence.

Proof. The fact that $\Phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ is nonempty, compact-valued, and upper hemicontinuous follows from standard arguments. We show that values are contractible. Fix $(\tau, \zeta)$ and some $\tilde{\tau} \in \Phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}(\tau, \zeta)$. Then $\tilde{\tau}=\tilde{\tau}^{\#} * \tilde{\tau}^{0}$. Consider the homotopy $J=J_{1} \times J_{2}: \Phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}(\tau, \zeta) \times[0,1] \rightarrow$ $\Phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}(\tau, \zeta)$ that for each $\tilde{\tau}=\left(\tilde{\tau}_{1}, \tilde{\tau}_{2}\right)=\left(\tilde{\tau}_{1}^{\#} * \tilde{\tau}_{1}^{0}, \tilde{\tau}_{2}^{\#} * \tilde{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right) \in \Phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}(\tau, \zeta)$ is defined by $J_{n}\left(t, \tilde{\tau}_{n}\right)=$

$\left[(1-t) \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{*}+t \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{*}\right] *\left[(1-t) \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{0}+t \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{0}\right]$ for each $n=1,2$. The homotopy is well-defined. Moreover, $J_{n}\left(0, \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{*} * \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{0}\right)=\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{*} * \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{0}$ and $J_{n}\left(1, \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{*} * \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{0}\right)=\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{*} * \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{0}$, which shows that $\Phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}(\tau, \zeta)$ is contractible valued.

Lemma 5.5. $\mathrm{BR}^{\times} \times \Phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ is a selection of $\mathrm{BR}^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$.
Proof. Let $(\hat{\zeta}, \tilde{\tau}) \in\left[\mathrm{BR}^{\times} \times \Phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}\right](\zeta, \tau)$. Since $\hat{\zeta} \in \mathrm{BR}^{\times}(\zeta, \tau)$ we only need to show $\tilde{\tau}_{n} \in \mathrm{BR}_{n}^{\circ, \varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}\left(\zeta_{-n}^{-n}, q_{-n}^{\circ}(\tau)\right)$ for $n=1,2$. By definition, $\tilde{\tau}_{n}=\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{*} * \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{0}$, where

$$
\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{\circ} \in q_{n}^{\circ}\left[\mathrm{BR}_{n}^{\circ, \varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}\left(\zeta_{-n}^{-n}, q_{-n}^{\circ}\left(\tau_{-n}\right)\right)\right]
$$

Therefore, there exists

$$
\tau_{n}^{\prime} \in \arg \max _{\tilde{\tau}_{n}}\left\{\varepsilon_{-n} \mathbb{G}_{n}\left(\tilde{\tau}_{n}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)+\left(1-\varepsilon_{1}-\varepsilon_{2}\right) \mathbb{G}_{n}\left(q_{n}^{\circ}\left(\tilde{\tau}_{n}\right), q_{-n}^{\circ}\left(\tau_{-n}\right)\right)\right\}
$$

such that $q_{n}^{\circ}\left(\tau_{n}^{\prime}\right)=\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{\circ}$. Take $\tau_{n}^{*}=\tau_{n}^{*, \circ} * \tau_{n}^{*, 0}$ equivalent to $\tau_{n}^{\prime}$ in $\mathbb{G}$. Then $\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{\circ}$ must be equivalent to $\tau_{n}^{*, \circ}$ in $\mathbb{G}^{\circ}$. Recall $\operatorname{Supp}\left(\tau_{n}^{*, \circ}\right) \subseteq \operatorname{Supp}\left(\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{\circ}\right)$ because $\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{\circ}$ is completely mixed. Hence,

$$
\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{0} \in \arg \max _{\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{0}} \sum_{s_{n}^{\circ}, s_{n}^{0}} \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{\circ}\left(s_{n}^{\circ}\right) \tau_{n}^{0}\left(s_{n}^{0}\right) \mathbb{G}_{n}\left(s_{n}^{\circ}, s_{n}^{0}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right) \subseteq \arg \max _{\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{0}} \sum_{s_{n}^{\circ}, s_{n}^{0}} \tau_{n}^{*, \circ}\left(s_{n}^{\circ}\right) \tau_{n}^{0}\left(s_{n}^{0}\right) \mathbb{G}_{n}\left(s_{n}^{\circ}, s_{n}^{0}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)
$$

That is,

$$
\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{\circ} * \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{0} \in \arg \max _{\tilde{\tau}_{n}}\left\{\varepsilon_{-n} \mathbb{G}_{n}\left(\tilde{\tau}_{n}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)+\left(1-\varepsilon_{1}-\varepsilon_{2}\right) \mathbb{G}_{n}\left(q_{n}^{\circ}\left(\tilde{\tau}_{n}\right), q_{-n}^{\circ}\left(\tau_{-n}\right)\right)\right\}
$$

which shows $\tilde{\tau}_{n} \in \mathrm{BR}_{n}^{\circ, \varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}\left(\zeta_{-n}^{-n}, q_{-n}^{\circ}\left(\tau_{-n}\right)\right)$ for $n=1,2$ and, therefore, $(\hat{\zeta}, \tilde{\tau}) \in \mathrm{BR}^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}(\zeta, \tau)$.
Letting $\mathrm{BR}^{\circ}$ be the best-reply correspondence in the game $\mathbb{G}^{\circ}$, let us define $\Phi \equiv \Phi^{0,0}=$ $e \circ\left(\mathrm{BR}_{2}^{1} \times \mathrm{BR}^{\circ} \times \mathrm{BR}_{1}^{2}\right) \circ w$. Similarly to $\Phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$, standard arguments show that $\Phi$ is upper hemicontinuous as well as nonempty, compact, and contractible valued.

# Lemma 5.6. The following statements hold: 

(1) The neighborhood $\mathscr{O}^{\delta}$ is admissible for $\mathrm{BR}^{\times} \times \Phi$.
(2) For $\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}>0$ sufficiently small, $\mathscr{O}^{\delta}$ is admissible for $\mathrm{BR}^{\times} \times \Phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$.
(3) For $\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}>0$ sufficiently small, $\mathrm{BR}^{\times} \times \Phi^{\varepsilon_{1}, \varepsilon_{2}}$ assigns the same index to $\mathscr{O}^{\delta}$ as $\mathrm{BR}^{\times} \times \Phi$ does.

Proof. To prove (1), let $(\zeta, \tau)$ be a fixed point of $\mathrm{BR}^{\times} \times \Phi$, where $(\zeta, \tau) \in \operatorname{cl}\left(\mathscr{O}^{\delta}\right)$. Then $\tau_{n}=\tau_{n}^{\circ} * \tau_{n}^{0}$ and $\tau_{n}^{\circ} \in B^{\delta}$. This implies that $\tau_{n}^{\circ}$ is equivalent to $\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{\circ}$ in $\mathbb{G}^{\circ}$. Therefore, $\zeta_{-n}^{-n} \in \mathrm{BR}_{-n}^{\times}\left(\tau_{n}\right)=$ $\mathrm{BR}_{-n}^{-n}\left(\tau_{n}^{0}\right)$. Moreover, by construction, $\tau_{n}^{0} \in \mathrm{BR}_{n}^{-n}\left(\zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)$. Hence, $\left(\tau_{n}^{0}, \zeta_{-n}^{-n}\right)$ is an equilibrium of $\mathbb{G}^{-n}$. # 5.2. Step 2: Perturbing the excluded game so that it has no equilibria in the supporting polytope 

From Step 1, assume without loss of generality that $K^{1}$ has index 0 . Lemma 5.10. There exists a game $\overline{\mathbb{G}}^{1}=\left(\bar{S}_{1}^{1}, \bar{S}_{2}^{0}, \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{1}^{1}, \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{2}^{1}\right)$ equivalent to $\mathbb{G}^{1}$ such that:
(1) Player 1's pure strategy set $\bar{S}_{1}^{1}$ is the collection of vertices of a polyhedral refinement $\mathscr{P}_{1}$ of a simplicial subdivision of $\overline{\mathbb{L}}_{1}^{1}$.
(2) Player 2's pure strategy set $\bar{S}_{2}^{0}$ is the collection of vertices of a polyhedral refinement $\mathscr{P}_{2}$ of $\Sigma_{2}^{1}$ for which no polyhedron of $\mathscr{S}_{2}$ that intersects $\bar{\partial} K_{2}^{1}$ has a point in common with $K_{2}^{1, \eta}$.
(3) There exists $\delta>0$, a $\delta$-perturbation $\overline{\mathbb{G}}^{1, \delta}$ of $\overline{\mathbb{G}}^{1}$ and, for each $\varepsilon>0$, an $\varepsilon$-perturbation $\overline{\mathbb{G}}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon}$ of $\overline{\mathbb{G}}^{1, \delta}$ such that for $n=1,2$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{n}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon}\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right)=\overline{\mathbb{G}}_{n}^{1, \delta}\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right)=\overline{\mathbb{G}}_{n}^{1}\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right) \text { if } s_{2} \notin K_{2}^{1, \eta} \text {, and } \\
& \lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{n}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon}\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right)=\overline{\mathbb{G}}_{n}^{1, \delta}\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right) \geq \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{n}^{1}\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right) \text { if } s_{2} \in K_{2}^{1,2 \eta} .
\end{aligned}
$$

(4) For each $n=1,2$ and $\varepsilon>0$ small enough, if mixed strategies $\sigma_{n} \neq \bar{\sigma}_{n}$ are equivalent in $\overline{\mathbb{G}}^{1, \delta}$ and $\sigma_{n}$ 's support is within the vertices of a polyhedron of $\mathscr{P}_{n}$ whereas $\bar{\sigma}_{n}$ 's is not, then, for every mixed strategy $\sigma_{-n}$, we have $\overline{\mathbb{G}}_{n}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon}\left(\sigma_{n}, \sigma_{-n}\right)>\overline{\mathbb{G}}_{n}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon}\left(\bar{\sigma}_{n}, \sigma_{-n}\right)$.
(5) For $\varepsilon>0$ small enough, the game $\overline{\mathbb{G}}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon}=\left(\bar{S}_{1}^{1}, \bar{S}_{2}^{0}, \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{1}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon}, \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{2}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon}\right)$ does not have an equilibrium in $\bar{K}^{1}$.

The construction of $\breve{G}^{1}$ in Lemma 5.10 follows closely the construction presented in Theorem 3 in GW. However, there are a few differences stemming from the fact that the supporting polytope may contain more than one equilibrium component of the excluded game. Parts (1) and (2) simply record that the strategies obtained in $\breve{G}^{1}$ are duplicates originating from vertices of a polyhedral subdivision of the strategy sets. This is needed so that (3) and (4) can be meaningfully stated and used in Section 5.3. Chiefly, in Part (3), $s_{2}$ can be viewed as a vertex of the polyhedral subdivision $\mathscr{P}_{2}$ of $\Sigma_{2}^{1}$; and (4) refers explicitly to the vertices of the polyhedral subdivision. The main difference with the construction in GW is (3). Within $\breve{K}^{1,2 \eta}$ the payoff perturbations are not necessarily arbitrarily small, i.e., the inequality may be strict. This contrasts with GW where all payoff perturbations can be made as small as desired. ${ }^{15}$
