# 5.3. Step 3: The equivalent game and its perturbation 

We construct a game $\breve{G}$ equivalent to $G$ and a perturbation of $\breve{G}$ that has no equilibrium in a neighborhood of the equivalent component of equilibria $\breve{K}$. The main idea is to perturb $G$ so that, with vanishing probability, player 1 is forced to play the game $\breve{G}^{1, \beta, \varepsilon}$ that has been defined in Step 2 and that has no equilibrium in $\breve{K}^{1}$. We show that, in this perturbed game, players' behavior induce an equilibrium of $\breve{G}^{1, \beta, \varepsilon}$ so that player 2's strategy cannot belong to the supporting polytope. This, in turn, implies that the perturbed game of $\breve{G}$ cannot have an equilibrium in the fixed original neighborhood of $\breve{K}$.

Henceforth, extend the original game $\mathbb{G}$ to the equivalent game $\breve{\mathbb{G}}$ in which player 1's strategy set is $S_{1} \cup \breve{S}_{1}^{1}$ and player 2's strategy set is $S_{2} \cup \breve{S}_{2}$, where

$$
\breve{S}_{2} \equiv\left\{\hat{\ell}_{2}^{*} * \hat{s}_{2}^{0} \mid \hat{s}_{2}^{0} \in \breve{S}_{2}^{0}\right\}
$$

The extension is by equivalence, i.e., by viewing each strategy in $\breve{S}_{1}^{1}$ as a duplicate of a strategy in $\Sigma_{1}^{1}$, and similarly, viewing each strategy in $\breve{S}_{2}$ as a duplicate of a strategy in $\Sigma_{2}$. Let $\breve{G}_{1}$ and $\breve{G}_{2}$ be the corresponding bilinear extensions of $\mathbb{G}_{1}$ and $\mathbb{G}_{2}$ to $\Delta\left(S_{1} \cup \breve{S}_{1}^{1}\right) \times \Delta\left(S_{2} \cup \breve{S}_{2}\right)$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\overline{\mathbb{G}}_{2}\left(\bar{\tau}_{1}^{1, k},(1-\beta) \bar{\tau}_{2}+\beta\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}^{*} * \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right)\right) & =\overline{\mathbb{G}}_{2}\left(\bar{\tau}_{1}^{1, k}, \sigma_{2}\right) \\
\overline{\mathbb{G}}_{2}^{1, \beta, \varepsilon_{k}}\left(\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1, k},(1-\beta) \bar{\tau}_{2}+\beta\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}^{*} * \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right)\right) & >(1-\beta) \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{2}^{1, \beta, \varepsilon_{k}}\left(\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1, k}, q_{2}^{0}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}\right)\right)-\beta B
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, it must be that $\beta=0$, so $\sigma_{2}=\bar{\tau}_{2}^{*} * \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0} \in \Delta\left(\bar{S}_{2}\right)$. Furthermore, $\bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}$ 's support must be within the set of vertices of a polyhedron in $\mathscr{P}_{2}$, otherwise player 2 can do strictly better by Lemma 5.10 (4). Hence, every $\bar{s}_{2}^{0} \in \bar{S}_{2}^{0}$ in $\bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}$ 's support satisfies $\bar{s}_{2}^{0} \notin \bar{K}_{2}^{1, \eta}$ (because of (2) in Lemma 5.10). On the other hand, both $\bar{\tau}_{1}^{1, k}$ and $\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1, k}$ must be optimal against $\sigma_{2}^{k}$ for every $k$. The last two facts together with Lemma 5.10 (3) imply that at the limit $\varepsilon_{k} \rightarrow 0$, for $k \rightarrow+\infty$, we have

$$
\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1} \in \arg \max _{x_{1} \in \Delta\left(\bar{S}_{1}^{1}\right)} \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{1}^{1}\left(x_{1}, \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \bar{\tau}_{1}^{1} \in \arg \max _{x_{1} \in \Delta\left(\bar{S}_{1}^{1}\right)} \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{1}\left(x_{1}, \bar{\tau}_{2}\right)
$$

Since $\bar{\tau}_{2}=\bar{\tau}_{2}^{*} * \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}$ strategy $\bar{\tau}_{1}^{1}$ is, in fact, a best-reply against $\bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}$ in the excluded game $\overline{\mathbb{G}}^{1}$. Thus, $\varphi \bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1}+(1-\varphi) \bar{\tau}_{1}^{1}$ is also a best-reply against $\bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}$ in $\overline{\mathbb{G}}^{1}$. Recall $\bar{\tau}_{2}^{0} \in \bar{\partial} K_{2}^{1}$, hence by Assumption A.2, player 2 must have a profitable deviation $\bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}$ in $\overline{\mathbb{G}}^{1}$, i.e.,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{2}^{1}\left(\varphi \bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1}+(1-\varphi) \bar{\tau}_{1}^{1}, \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right)>\overline{\mathbb{G}}_{2}^{1}\left(\varphi \bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1}+(1-\varphi) \bar{\tau}_{1}^{1}, \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right)=\varphi \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{2}^{1}\left(\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1}, \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right)+(1-\varphi) \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{2}^{1}\left(\bar{\tau}_{1}^{1}, \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right)= \\
& \lim _{k \rightarrow \infty}\left\{\varphi^{k} \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{2}^{1, \beta, \varepsilon_{k}}\left(\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1, k}, \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right)+\left(1-\varphi^{k}\right) \overline{\mathbb{G}}_{2}\left(\bar{\tau}_{1}^{1, k}, \bar{\tau}_{2}^{*} * \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right)\right\},
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last equality uses Lemma 5.10 (3) since $\bar{\tau}_{2}^{0} \notin \bar{K}_{2}^{1, \eta}$. Similarly,
$\bar{G}_{2}^{1}\left(\varphi \bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1}+(1-\varphi) \bar{\tau}_{1}^{1}, \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right)=\varphi \bar{G}_{2}^{1}\left(\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1}, \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right)+(1-\varphi) \bar{G}_{2}^{1}\left(\bar{\tau}_{1}^{1}, \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right) \leq \lim _{k \rightarrow \infty}\left\{\varphi^{k} \bar{G}_{2}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon_{k}}\left(\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1, k}, \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right)+\left(1-\varphi^{k}\right) \bar{G}_{2}\left(\bar{\tau}_{1}^{1, k}, \bar{\tau}_{2}^{\oplus} * \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}\right)\right\}$,
where we have used again Lemma 5.10 (3) in the last inequality. From this we have a contradiction given that $\bar{\tau}_{2}^{\oplus} * \bar{\tau}_{2}^{0}$ does strictly better than $\bar{\tau}_{2}$ for large enough $k$.
Claim 5.13. For $k$ large enough, $\left(\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1, k}, q_{2}^{0}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}^{k}\right)\right)$ is an equilibrium of $\bar{G}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon_{k}}$.
Proof. From Claim 5.12, for $k$ sufficiently large, $\alpha_{k}=0$. For such a $k$, player 2's expected payoff from playing $\sigma_{2}^{k}=\left(1-\beta_{k}\right) \bar{\tau}_{2}^{k}+\beta_{k} \tau_{2}^{k}$ against $\sigma_{1}^{k}$ is equal to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \varepsilon_{k}\left\{\left(1-\beta_{k}\right) \bar{G}_{2}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon_{k}}\left(\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1, k}, q_{2}^{0}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}^{k}\right)\right)-\beta_{k} B\right\}+\left(1-\varepsilon_{k}\right)\left[\bar{G}_{2}\left(\tau_{1}^{\times, k},\left(1-\beta_{k}\right) \bar{\tau}_{2}^{k}+\beta_{k} \tau_{2}^{k}\right)\right]= \\
& \varepsilon_{k}\left\{\left(1-\beta_{k}\right) \bar{G}_{2}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon_{k}}\left(\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1, k}, q_{2}^{0}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}^{k}\right)\right)-\beta_{k} B\right\}+\left(1-\varepsilon_{k}\right)\left\{\left(1-\beta_{k}\right) \bar{G}_{2}^{\oplus}\left(q_{1}^{\oplus}\left(\tau_{1}^{\times, k}\right), \bar{\tau}_{2}^{\oplus}\right)+\beta_{k} \bar{G}_{2}\left(\tau_{1}^{\times, k}, \tau_{2}^{k}\right)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Repeating similar arguments to the proof of Claim 5.12 we obtain $\beta_{k} \rightarrow 0$. From (13) we therefore see that, for $k$ large enough, $q_{2}^{0}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}^{k}\right)$ must be a best-reply to $\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1, k}$ in $\bar{G}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon_{k}}$. In turn, $\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1, k}$ must also be best-reply to $q_{2}^{0}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}^{k}\right)$. That is, $\left(\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1, k}, q_{2}^{0}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}^{k}\right)\right)$ is an equilibrium of $\bar{G}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon_{k}}$.

Let $\left(\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1}, q_{2}^{0}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}\right)\right)$ be a limit of $\left(\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1, k}, q_{2}^{0}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}^{k}\right)\right)_{k \in \mathbb{N}}$, that is, an equilibrium of $\bar{G}^{1, \delta, 0}$. By construction, $\left(\bar{\zeta}_{1}^{1}, q_{2}^{0}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}\right)\right)$ belongs to the complement of $\bar{K}^{1}$. Therefore, by definition of $\bar{K}^{1}$, there exists a pure strategy $\bar{s}_{1}^{1}$ such that $\bar{G}_{1}^{1, \delta, 0}\left(\bar{s}_{1}^{1}, \bar{\tau}_{2}^{\oplus} * q_{2}^{0}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}\right)\right))=\bar{G}_{1}\left(\bar{s}_{1}^{1}, \bar{\tau}_{2}^{\oplus} * q_{2}^{0}\left(\bar{\tau}_{2}\right)\right)>G_{1}(Q)$, where the equality comes from Lemma 5.10 (3). Hence, $\sigma \notin \bar{K}$, which implies $\sigma^{k} \notin \bar{\ell}$ for sufficiently large $k$. This contradicts our initial assumption. We conclude that there is no sequence of equilibria of $\bar{G}^{\varepsilon_{k}}$ that converges to some point in $\bar{\ell}$.
Example 5.14. We finish the example started in Section 1.1 using the same construction as in Figure 6. Since the game equivalent to player 1's excluded game has the same strategy space as the excluded game itself, it is enough to "plug" the perturbed version found in Example 5.11 after $\kappa_{2}$. See Figure 7 for the resulting game. Following the same line of reasoning as in the general case above, note that player 1 cannot be made indifferent between In and Out at the limit of a sequence of equilibria as $\varepsilon$ goes to zero. If that was the case, player 2 would be playing $\ell$ with probability close to $2 / 3$ along the sequence which, in turn, implies that player 1 would be playing $T$ and $\bar{T}$ with probability 1 and, therefore, player 2 would have a profitable deviation to playing $\ell$ with probability 1 . Hence, if there is an equilibrium close to the "Out"-component then, for any $\varepsilon>0$, player 1 must strictly prefer playing Out and player 2 would be choosing her strategy as if she was best-replying to player 1's move after $\kappa_{2}$. That is, player 2 would be choosing $\ell$ with probability 1 . But then, player 1 would have an incentive to deviate to In and then choose $T$. We conclude that the perturbed game has no equilibrium close to the "Out"-component and, correspondingly, that such a component is not hyperstable in the original game.

# 6. APPLICATIONS 

In this section we analyze some examples including a few prominent models in the economics literature and show how index computation can be used to eliminate non-hyperstable

Figure 7. A perturbation of a game equivalent to Figure 1
![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)
equilibria. We begin by revisiting the game in Figure 1 and showing that the recent refinement concept of sequentially stable outcomes of Dilmé (2024) diverges from hyperstability. We then move to study two finitely repeated games. In particular, Example 6.3 illustrates how relying only on pure-strategy subgame-perfect equilibria to analyze these games may lead to selecting equilibrium outcomes that have index zero. We conclude by analyzing some classical signaling games. This serves both to compare hyperstabily to other equilibrium concepts and to highlight how hyperstable components are easy to compute through their index. In preparation for the examples, we note a novel way to compute the index of a component using the indexes of the supporting polytopes in their corresponding excluded games. The following result is a corollary from the arguments in Section 5.1.
Proposition 6.1. Let $G$ be a two-player extensive-form game with normal form $\mathbb{G}$. Let $K$ be a component for which assumptions A. 1 and A. 2 are satisfied. Letting $K^{*}=q^{*}(K)$ be the projected component in game $\mathbb{G}^{*}$, the index of component $K$ in game $\mathbb{G}$, written as $\operatorname{Ind}_{\mathbb{G}}(K)$, can be decomposed as follows

$$
\operatorname{Ind}_{\mathbb{G}}(K)=\operatorname{Ind}_{\mathbb{G}^{1}}\left(K^{1}\right) \times \operatorname{Ind}_{\mathbb{G}^{*}}\left(K^{*}\right) \times \operatorname{Ind}_{\mathbb{G}^{2}}\left(K^{2}\right)
$$

where, by convention, $\operatorname{Ind}_{\mathbb{G}^{n}}\left(K^{n}\right) \equiv 1$ if player $n$ does not have an excluded game.
Example 6.2. Sequential equilibrium is one of the most prominent solution concepts in extensive-form games as it extends the principle of backward induction to imperfect information games. However, it has shortcomings which have been extensively discussed in the literature (Kohlberg and Mertens, 1986; Cho and Kreps, 1987). Sequentially stable outcomes, recently defined by (Dilmé, 2024), refine the set of sequential equilibrium outcomes.

Roughly, an outcome $\omega$ is sequentially stable if for any vanishing sequence of behavioral trembles, there exists a sequence of $\varepsilon$-sequential equilibria of the (trembled)-game (with vanishing $\varepsilon>0$ ) inducing outcomes which converge to $\omega$ (see Dilmé, 2024, p. 9 for the definition). Note that while the definition of hyperstability considers payoff perturbations explicitly, by invoking $\varepsilon$-sequential equilibria, sequentially stable outcomes considers payoff perturbations implicitly.

Sequentially stable outcomes are a natural refinement of sequential equilibrium. They appropriately refine the set of equilibria in some examples while perhaps being equally

Figure 8. Equivalent Entry game
![img-7.jpeg](img-7.jpeg)
tractable. Unfortunately, similarly to sequential equilibrium, sequentially stable outcomes rely on the specifics of the extensive-form. Hence, contrasting with hyperstability, they do not satisfy invariance. ${ }^{16}$ We can illustrate this difference returning to Figure 1. It can be easily checked that "Out" is a sequential equilibrium outcome. It is also a sequentially stable outcome (which can be seen by applying Dilmé, 2024, Proposition 4.3, Part 2). However, "Out" is not selected by either concept in the well-known equivalent representation of the game provided in Figure 8 (cf. Hillas, 1994). After adding the redundant strategy $X$, the unique equilibrium of the subgame that follows In is $(L, \ell)$, making $(\operatorname{In}-L, \ell)$ the unique Sequential Equilibrium (or Sequentially Stable) outcome. Not surprisingly, the forward induction outcome ( $\operatorname{In}-L, \ell$ ) is the unique equilibrium selected by hyperstability both in in the representation of Figure 1 and in the representation of Figure 8. (Hyperstability can be computed directly in the latter game by noticing that player 1's excluded game associated with "Out" does not have any equilibrium in the supporting polytope, implying that the supporting polytope has index 0 and, by Proposition 6.1, component "Out" also has index 0, i.e., it is not hyperstable.)

We move to study a finitely repeated game. As we show below, finitely repeated games have a recursive structure that aids the computation of the index of equilibrium outcomes. ${ }^{17}$

Example 6.3. The repeated game with stage-game in Figure 9 is taken from Mailath and Samuelson (2006, Example 4.4.1). The game has 3 equilibria in pure strategies $(A, A)$, $(B, B)$ and $(C, C)$ and 4 equilibria in mixed strategies $\left(\frac{1}{5} A+\frac{4}{5} B, \frac{3}{7} A+\frac{4}{7} B\right),\left(\frac{1}{5} A+\frac{4}{5} C, \frac{1}{3} A+\frac{2}{3} C\right)$, $\left(\frac{3}{4} B+\frac{1}{4} C, \frac{1}{4} B+\frac{3}{4} C\right)$ and $\left(\frac{1}{17} A+\frac{12}{17} B+\frac{4}{17} C, \frac{3}{13} A+\frac{4}{13} B+\frac{6}{13} C\right)$. Pure strategy equilibria are strict and therefore have index +1 . Mixed strategy equilibria that are not completely mixed have

Examples such as the twice-repeated Prisoners Dilemma do not allow for equilibria where in the first stage a profile different from the unique equilibrium of the stage game is played. This contrasts with this example where the stage-game has more than one equilibrium that can be used differently to punish/reward players in the associated finitely repeated game, and allows for subgame perfect equilibrium outcomes in which a profile that is not necessarily an equilibrium of the stage-game to be played in early stages. Indeed, Mailath and Samuelson (2006, p. 113) note that, if the game in Figure 9 is played twice, then it is possible to support $(C, A)$ in the first period in subgame perfect equilibrium by playing $(A, A)$ in the second stage if no player deviated in the first stage, $(B, B)$ if the second player deviated, and $(C, C)$ if the first player deviated. We show in this particular case that supporting the non-equilibrium profile in the first stage is not plausible (from the point of view of hyperstability). To be precise, we show that the component $K$ which induces the outcome " 6,6 " in which players play on-path $(C, A)$ and then $(A, A)$ is not hyperstable.

First, we note that such an outcome is not isolated in the set of equilibrium outcomes. Indeed, if " 2,6 " is the outcome in which players play on-path $(C, C)$ twice, the same equilibrium component induces the continuum of outcomes $\alpha " 6,6 "+(1-\alpha)^{\prime \prime} 2,6 "$ for $0 \leq \alpha \leq 1$. Therefore, Assumption A. 1 is not satisfied and we cannot directly apply the results in this paper to analyze the equilibrium component $K$. Nonetheless, we can use Property I. 1 and perturb player 2's payoffs slightly so that, in the first stage, her payoff is $3-\varepsilon$ under profile $(C, C)$ with $\varepsilon>0$. Call the resulting perturbed game $G(\varepsilon)$. The index of any small enough admissible neighbourhood $\mathscr{O}$ of $K$ in the original game coincides with the index of $\mathscr{O}$ in $G(\varepsilon)$ provided $\varepsilon>0$ is small enough. Furthermore, in $G(\varepsilon)$, the unique component in $\mathscr{O}$ does induce a unique outcome and, in this unique outcome, players play on path $(C, A)$ and then $(A, A)$.

Let us compute player 1's excluded game under such an outcome. Since it does not depend on $\varepsilon$, we simply denote it as $\mathbb{G}^{1}$. Any deviation that involves player 1 playing $B$ in the first stage gives player 1 a payoff of at most 3 , which is strictly smaller that her payoff of 6 under the equilibrium component. Therefore, we may only consider player 1's deviations in which she plays $A$ in the first stage. After eliminating duplicates, player 1's (simplified) excluded game is represented in Figure 10 (left). Note that payoffs are obtained from Figure 9 after

Example 6.4. van Damme (1989) shows that in the two-fold repetition of the stage game in Figure 11 the outcomes in which players either play $(T, L)$ or $(B, R)$ twice is not stable in the sense of Kohlberg and Mertens (1986) whereas the outcome in which players alternate is, in turn, stable. In addition, van Damme (1989, p. 429) also points out that "[c]omputing the set of all stable equilibrium paths seems to be laborious, however, even in this most simple conceivable case." Here, we illustrate how the properties of the index and the results in this paper can be used to compute the index of every equilibrium component in this repeated game. We also note that every nonzero index component contains a stable set (both in the sense of Kohlberg and Mertens, 1986, and in the sense of Mertens, 1989.)

Call $G$ the two-fold repetition of the game in Figure 11. The stage game of $G$ has 3 equilibria. The two pure equilibria $(T, L)$ and $(B, R)$ are strict and therefore have index +1 . The completely mixed equilibrium $\left(\frac{4}{5} T+\frac{1}{5} B, \frac{1}{5} L+\frac{4}{5} R\right)$ has index -1 .

First, every equilibrium component in which players play a completely mixed action profile in the first period has nonzero index. Indeed, if in such a component players always play the completely mixed equilibrium of the stage game after any realization in the first stage, then this equilibrium component induces a completely mixed outcome which, therefore has nonzero index (cf. Proposition 2.3). On the other hand, if for some realization in the first stage, players play a strict equilibrium in the second stage then every observable deviation

consists of deviating in the second stage from the prescribed strict equilibrium. Those deviations are inferior responses to the equilibrium outcome and after eliminating them the outcome is completely mixed and, therefore, has nonzero index.

Let " 8,2 " be the equilibrium outcome in which players play $(T, L)$ twice. Using a similar argument as above, deviating only in the second stage is an inferior response to the equilibrium outcome. After eliminating those deviations from $G$, we can see that player 1 has (after eliminating duplicates) only 2 observable deviations, $B T$ and $B B$ (that is, playing $B$ in the first stage and then playing either $T$ or $B$ in the subgame that follows $(B, L)$ ). Player 2's strategy set in player 1's excluded game is $\{L, R\}$. Note that if player 1 deviates to either $B T$ or $B B$ in $G$ then the payoff vector accrued in the first stage is $(0,0)$ given that player 2 is playing $L$ in such a stage. Therefore, the excluded game $\mathbb{G}^{1}$ coincides with the game in Figure 11.

Player 1's payoff in $\mathbb{G}^{1}$ is always strictly smaller than player 1's payoff of 8 if $(T, L)$ is played twice. Hence, the supporting polytope $K^{1}$ coincides with the entire strategy space in $\mathbb{G}^{1}$ which implies that $K^{1}$ has index +1 in $\mathbb{G}^{1}$. In turn, consider player 2's observable deviations $R L$ and $R R$. The excluded game $\mathbb{G}^{2}$ again coincides with the game in Figure 11.

The supporting polytope $K^{2}$ requires player 1 to play $B$ with probability smaller or equal than 0.5 . The only equilibrium that lies outside that region is $(B, R)$ which is strict and, therefore, has index +1 . Thus, the supporting polytope $K^{2}$ has zero index in game $\mathbb{G}^{2}$. Proposition 6.1 implies that the component " 8,2 " has zero index and, therefore, it is not hyperstable. The analogous argument of course holds for the equilibrium component " $2,8^{\prime \prime}$. It also holds for the equilibrium outcome in which players play the completely mixed equilibrium of the stage game after playing one of the strict equilibria in the first stage.

Finally, consider now the two equilibrium outcomes " 5,5 ", one in which players play $(T, L)$ first and $(B, R)$ second, and the other in which this order is reversed. In both cases player 1 and player 2's excluded games coincide with the game in Figure 11. Thus, every payoff in the two excluded games associated to the corresponding equilibrium component is smaller for both players than the payoff 5 induced by the equilibrium outcome. This implies that both supporting polytopes have index +1 and, therefore, the two components that induce the equilibrium payoff vector $(5,5)$ also have index +1 and are hyperstable.

We now turn our attention to signaling games. Signaling games have driven the creation of a wealth of refinement concepts to eliminate implausible equilibria. Some of the most well-known are the Intuitive Criterion, D1, D2, Never-weak-best-reply (NWBR), and Universal Divinity. Hyperstability is strictly stronger than any of these criteria and, as we show, it is easy to compute by using properties of the index. The next proposition is known but we recall it for completeness.

Figure 12. Beer-and-Quiche Game
![img-8.jpeg](img-8.jpeg)

Proposition 6.5. Let $G$ be a finite signaling game. Suppose the terminal payoffs of $G$ are chosen according to A. 1 and A. 2 and $Q$ is an equilibrium outcome which is hyperstable. Then $Q$ satisfies the Intuitive Criterion, D1, D2, NWBR and Universal Divinity.

The result follows from observing that a stable outcome in the sense of Kohlberg and Mertens (1986) satisfies all the criteria listed above and that every hyperstable outcome is also Kohlberg-Mertens stable.

Example 6.6. Consider the Beer-Quiche Game from Cho and Kreps (1987) (see Figure 12). The game has two equilibrium outcomes. In the first one, Sender chooses Beer $(B)$ for both of his types and Receiver, seeing this, does Not Fight ( $N F$ ). Off the equilibrium path, Receiver Fights $(F)$ with probability at least 0.5 . This equilibrium outcome survives all the classical refinements listed in Cho and Kreps and there are good reasons for it to be selected (see Cho and Kreps, 1987, pp. 184-185). In the other equilibrium outcome, Sender chooses Quiche $(Q)$ for both of his types and, upon seeing this, Receiver does not fight. To prevent the strong type ( $S$ ) from deviating to Beer ( $B$ ), Receiver fights with probability at least 0.5 off the equilibrium path. Cho and Kreps provide intuitive reasons under which Receiver's off-equilibrium beliefs are implausible (see p.185) and this equilibrium outcome does not survive the Intuitive Criterion. Therefore, it is not hyperstable (see Proposition 6.5). But we can verify this directly by computing the index of the second equilibrium outcome.

Sender's excluded game associated to this equilibrium outcome is in the right-hand side of Figure 12 where $Q B$, for instance, is the deviation in which sender chooses $Q$ after $S$ and $B$ after $W$. First note that the supporting polytope consists of those strategy profiles in the excluded game whose payoff to Sender is smaller than or equal to $\frac{21}{10}$ (i.e. her payoff under the $Q Q-N F$ component). In this excluded game, $B B$ is strictly dominated. Furthermore, the excluded game has three equilibria, $(B Q, N F),(Q B, F)$, and $\left(\frac{1}{10} B Q+\frac{9}{10} Q B, \frac{3}{8} N F+\frac{5}{8} F\right)$. Sender's payoff under these equilibria is, respectively, $3, \frac{9}{5}$, and $\frac{18}{5}$. That is, only the last two belong to the supporting polytope and, since strict equilibria have index +1 and the sum of all the indexes must be equal to +1 , the index of the supporting polytope is zero. Proposition 6.1 implies that $Q Q-N F$ has index zero and, consequently, it is not hyperstable.

Figure 13. Figure IV in Cho \& Kreps
![img-9.jpeg](img-9.jpeg)

Example 6.7. Consider the game in Cho and Kreps (1987, Figure IV, p. 207) and represented in Figure 13. The game has two equilibrium outcomes. In the first, both types send $m^{\prime}$ and, off the equilibrium path, Receiver plays in the convex hull of $(2 / 3,0,1 / 3)$, $(1 / 6,1 / 2,1 / 3),(0,1 / 2,1 / 2)$ and $(0,0,1)$ where probabilities in each vector correspond, in order, to strategies $r_{1}, r_{2}$ and $r_{3}$. This first component satisfies the Intuitive Criterion, $D 1$, $D 2$, and Universal Divinity. In the second equilibrium outcome both types send $m$ and Receiver plays $r_{2}$. Since the second equilibrium outcome is induced by a strict equilibrium (hence with index +1 ) and the indexes of all equilibria always add up to +1 (Property I.3) the first component has zero index. While simple, this reasoning requires knowing all the equilibrium outcomes but, as before, we can also directly compute its index.

Sender's excluded game in the component is on the right-hand side of Figure 13. Its unique equilibrium is $\left(m m, r_{2}\right)$ and it lies outside the supporting polytope which, consequently, has index zero. Therefore, by Proposition 6.1, the $m^{\prime} m^{\prime}$ component has index zero and, therefore, it is not hyperstable.

Example 6.8. We move to the example in Cho and Kreps (1987, p.216) represented in Figure 14. This example illustrates how Kohlberg-Mertens stability is strictly stronger than NWBR, D1, D2, Universal Divinity, and the Intuitive Criterion. Similarly to the previous example, this game has two equilibrium outcomes. The first one is the strict equilibrium ( $m m^{\prime} m^{\prime}, r_{1}$ ), where $m m^{\prime} m^{\prime}$ means player 1 plays $m$ in his leftmost information set, and $m^{\prime}$ in the middle and rightmost information sets. Hence, the other equilibrium outcome in which all three types send $m^{\prime}$ must have index 0 and not be hyperstable. The formal argument sketched by Cho and Kreps that verifies that the second equilibrium outcome is not Kohlberg-Mertens stable (although satisfying all other refinement criteria) is more involved than what we showed here and, because of the unintuitive nature of their characterization of stability, less convincing. ${ }^{19}$ In contrast, using the properties of the index, identifying hyperstability is easy. Its intuitiveness comes from the fact that it captures payoff robustness in every equivalent game.

The supporting polytope in Sender's excluded game is a polyhedron obtained by permuting the vector $(2 / 3,1 / 3,0)$ in Receiver's mixed strategy set. This supporting polytope contains

Example 6.9. We conclude with a finite game version of Spence's job-market model in Figure 15. There are two equilibrium outcomes, one pooling and one separating and hyperstability selects the separating equilibrium outcome. We can analyze the game in the same manner as the Beer-and-Quiche game to show that the pooling equilibrium (where the Sender sends $e$ for both types, and the Receiver replies with $w$ on equilibrium path, and off equilibrium path, with a probability of $w$ at least $1 / 2$ ) has index 0 .

Interestingly, when we consider the general Spence model (Cho and Kreps, 1987, Section V) with any number of types and a continuum of education levels and wages, the same reasoning can be used to eliminate any pooling or semi-pooling equilibrium outcome, leaving only the fully separating one (the so-called Riley outcome) left. To show that, consider a (semi-)pooling equilibrium outcome where a certain number of types pool at education level $e_{p}$. To prevent the highest of the pooling types, denoted $\theta^{*}$, from deviating from $e_{p}$ to a higher education level $e>e_{p}$ where the associated equilibrium wage $w(e)<\left(\theta^{*} e\right)$ is offered (off-path) after $e$ renders a deviation of all pooling types but $\theta^{*}$ to $e$ a strictly inferior reply (this follows from single-crossing). Therefore, we can eliminate all corresponding pure strategies that assign $e$ to all such pooling types. After this elimination, the extensive-form has a subgame after education level $e$. Backward induction now implies that firms bestreply with wage level $\left(\theta^{*} e\right)>w(e)$, which upsets the (semi-)pooling equilibrium.

We emphasize that the characterization in our main theorem is not known to hold in this infinite dimensional setting. The purpose here is only to remark that the same two principles invoked previously to compute the index in the finite game setting (elimination of strictly inferior replies and backward induction) can also be invoked in the Spence model to eliminate pooling and semi-pooling equilibria.

# APPENDix A. Proof of Proposition 2.3 

We introduce enabling strategies. Fix a two-player finite game tree $\Gamma$. For each player $n=1,2$ and $z \in Z$, let $A_{n}(z)$ be the set of Player $n$ 's actions that precede $z$. The set of Player $n$ 's actions that are $\prec$-maximal in $A_{n}(z)$ for some $z \in Z$ are denoted $L_{n}$ and called Player $n$ 's last actions in $\Gamma$. If $L_{n}=\varnothing$ then $n$ is a dummy player. Player $n$ 's last action that precedes $z$ is $\ell_{n}(z)$. Given last action $i \in L_{n}$, let $u \in U_{n}$ satisfy $i \in A_{n}(u)$. The subset $S_{n}(i) \subset S_{n}$ consists of those strategies that at every information set $u^{\prime}$ of Player $n$ that precede $u$ prescribe the unique action leading to $u$. Define $q_{n}^{e}: \Sigma_{n} \rightarrow[0,1]^{L_{n}}$ so that for every $\sigma_{n} \in \Sigma_{n}$ and $i \in L_{n}$ we have $q_{n}^{e}\left(\sigma_{n}\right) \equiv\left(\sum_{s_{n} \in S_{n}(i)} \sigma_{n}\left(s_{n}\right)\right)_{i \in L_{n}}$. The map $q_{n}^{e}$ is affine and therefore $C_{n} \equiv q_{n}^{e}\left(\Sigma_{n}\right)$ is a polytope in $\mathbb{R}^{L_{n}}$. The polytope $C_{n}$ is the enabling strategy set of Player $n$. If Nature moves in $\Gamma$ we analogously denote the set of Nature's last moves by $L_{0}$. Denote $L \equiv L_{0} \times L_{1} \times L_{2}$.

Given extensive-form payoffs $G \in \mathscr{G}$ and a profile of enabling strategies $\left(c_{1}, c_{2}\right) \in C \equiv C_{1} \times$ $C_{2}$, we construct payoffs are as follows. First, for every Nature's last move $i_{0} \in L_{0}$, define $c_{0}\left(i_{0}\right) \equiv \prod_{i_{0}^{\prime} \in A_{0}, i^{\prime} \leq i_{0}} \varrho\left(i_{0}^{\prime}\right)$. Each of Player $n$ 's last action in $L_{n}$ is associated with a unique sequence of Player $n$ 's past actions that lead to the information set in which such a last action is available. Therefore, a vector of last actions $i=\left(i_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}\right)$ either defines a path from the root to a terminal node or it does not. In the latter case, define $g_{n}(i) \equiv 0$. In the former case, letting $z$ be the terminal nodes that is reached by such path, define $g_{n}(i) \equiv G_{n}(z)$. Player $n$ 's enabling payoff function $V_{n}^{e}: C \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is defined by

$$
V_{n}^{e}(c) \equiv \sum_{i \in L} g_{n}(i) c_{0}\left(i_{0}\right) c_{1}\left(i_{1}\right) c_{2}\left(i_{2}\right)
$$

Note that the payoff function $V_{n}^{e}$ is affine in each coordinate and, therefore, defines a polytopeform game $\mathfrak{V}^{e}=\left(C_{1}, C_{2}, V_{1}^{e}, V_{2}^{e}\right)$ which is called the enabling-form of $G$.

To prove Proposition 2.3, let $d_{n}$ be the dimension of $C_{n}$. Since $K$ induces a unique outcome with full support, then $q^{e}(K)=p$ is an isolated equilibrium in enabling strategies, located in the interior of $C$. For each $n=1,2$, take a $d_{n}$-simplex $F_{n}$ contained in the relative interior of the enabling strategy set $C_{n}$ and containing $p_{n}$ in its relative interior. If we restrict the enabling payoff function $V_{n}^{e}$ to $D_{n}$, then this defines a normal-form game with an isolated

completely mixed equilibrium $p$, with the same index as the polytope-form index of the enabling-form (cf. Pahl, 2023). It is known that completely mixed isolated equilibria of normal-form games have indexes +1 or -1 , since the payoff matrices are non-singular (and Shapley's formula gives their index, see Shapley, 1974). In particular, $p$ has non-zero index. The equivalence between the index in normal and polytope forms (cf. Pahl, 2023) then implies that $K$ has non-zero index.

# Appendix B. Proof of Proposition 4.3 

Fix a two-player game-tree $\Gamma$ with perfect recall. The set of terminal nodes is $Z$ and the set of terminal payoffs is denoted $\mathbb{R}^{2|Z|}$. A typical element of $\mathbb{R}^{2|Z|}$ is denoted $G$. We describe a system of polynomial equations whose zeros essentially correspond to an assignment of payoffs $G$ and: (i) an equilibrium of $G$ in behavior strategies; (ii) a deviation behavior strategy of player 1 that grants him the same payoff as on-path; (iii) player 2 also best-replies to the deviation strategy of player 1 . We prove that set of payoffs at which these three conditions are satisfied has dimension strictly lower than $2|Z|$. The proof where the roles of players 1 and 2 are reversed is obviously analogous. This implies our desired result.

We start with preliminary definitions required to describe the system. Recall that, given player $n=1,2$, a behavior strategy $b_{n}=\left(b_{n}(i)\right)_{i \in A_{n}}$ satisfies $\left(b_{n}(i)\right)_{i \in A_{n}(u)} \in \Delta\left(A_{n}(u)\right)$ for every $u \in U_{n}$. Given player 1's set of actions $A_{1}$, consider subsets $C_{1}$ and $C_{1}^{\prime}$ such that (1) $C_{1} \cup C_{1}^{\prime}=$ $A_{1}$ and $C_{1} \cap C_{1}^{\prime}=\varnothing$ and (2) each action in $C_{1}$ has all predecessors in $C_{1}$ or no predecessor. Note that there are finitely many pairs $\left(C_{1}, C_{1}^{\prime}\right)$ satisfying this condition. For each $n=1,2$, the collection $U_{n}^{+}\left(C_{1}\right) \subset U_{n}$ is made of those information sets of player $n$ that can be reached (for some strategy of player 2) when player 1 is restricted to choosing actions in $C_{1}$. Let $U_{n}^{0}\left(C_{1}\right) \equiv U_{n} \backslash U_{n}^{+}\left(C_{1}\right)$, i.e., the set of information sets of player $n$ that can be reached when player 1 plays an action in $C_{1}^{\prime}$ with positive probability. If $b_{n}$ is a behavior strategy of player $n$, then $b_{n}^{+}$and $b_{n}^{0}$ are the restrictions to, respectively, $U_{n}^{+}\left(C_{1}\right)$ and $U_{n}^{0}\left(C_{1}\right)$. Note that the definition of $G_{1, u, i}^{+}\left(b_{1}^{+}, b_{2}^{+}\right)$can be generalized to $G_{1, u, i}^{0}\left(b_{1}^{+}, b_{2}^{+}, b_{1}^{0}, b_{2}^{0}\right)$, by requiring (i) and (ii) for $u \in U_{1}^{0}\left(C_{1}\right)$ and $i \in A_{n}(u)$, or $u \in U_{1}^{+}\left(C_{1}\right)$ and $i \in A_{n}(u) \cap C^{\prime}$ and letting play at all other information sets be directed by $\left(b_{1}^{+}, b_{2}^{+}, b_{1}^{0}, b_{2}^{0}\right)$. Suppose now that $\left|U_{2}^{0}\left(C_{1}\right)\right| \geq 1$ so that:

$$

Let $\alpha$ denote an arbitrary probability distribution over $\bar{C}_{1}$. Note that for any $\alpha$, there exists a behavior strategy $b_{1}^{\prime}$ for player 1 that induces $\alpha>0$ in the following sense:

$$
\alpha(i)=\frac{\prod_{j \leq i} b_{1}^{\prime}(j)}{\sum_{i^{\prime} \in \bar{C}_{1}} \prod_{j \leq i^{\prime}} b_{1}^{\prime}(j)} \text { for each } i \in \bar{C}_{1}
$$

For $u \in U_{2}^{0}$, let $G_{2, u, i}^{0}\left(\alpha, b_{1}^{0}, b_{2}^{0}\right)$ be the payoff to player 2 when (i) at every information set of player 2 that precedes $u$, player 2 plays the unique action that leads to $u$, (ii) the probability distribution $\alpha$, together with $b_{1}^{0}$, is used to compute beliefs at $u$, in the sense that any $b_{1}^{\prime}$ inducing $\alpha$ is used together with $b_{1}^{0}$ to compute beliefs at $u$, (iii) player 2 chooses action $i \in A_{2}(u)$; and (iv) play at every other information set in $U_{1}^{0}\left(C_{1}\right) \cup U_{2}^{0}\left(C_{1}\right)$ is prescribed by $\left(b_{1}^{0}, b_{2}^{0}\right) .^{20}$

Note that $(\alpha, \beta)$ is in $\mathbb{R}_{++}^{A}: \beta$ in particular can be seen as a collection of two subcollections of variables, $\beta_{1}$ for player 1 and $\beta_{2}$ for player $2 . \beta_{1}$ comprises the collection of real variables of player $1\left(\beta_{1, u, i}\right)$ where $u$ is an information set of player 1 in $U_{1}^{+}\left(C_{1}\right)$ and $i$ an action available at that information set; or $u$ is an information set in $U_{1}^{0}\left(C_{1}\right)$ and $i$ an action available at that information set. The set of zeros of the polynomial system is denoted $M$. Note that any $b_{1}^{\prime}$ which induces $\alpha$ is such that the beliefs induced on each information set of $U_{2}^{0}\left(C_{1}\right)$ that is reached in $\left(b_{1}^{\prime}, \beta_{2}\right)$ with positive probability

If the assumption we made above (i.e. $\left|\hat{U}_{2}^{0}\left(C_{1}\right)\right| \geq 1$ ) does not hold, then no information set of player 2 is excluded when player 1 randomizes in $C_{1}$. We have therefore obtained that $M$ is a semi-algebraic surface of dimension less than $2|Z|-1$. To finalize the argument, we need the following lemma (Bochnak et al., 1998, Theorem 2.8.8).

Lemma B.1. If $X$ is a semi-algebraic set and $f: X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m}$ is a semi-algebraic function then $\operatorname{dim}(f(X)) \leq \operatorname{dim}(X)$.

Theorem B.2. The subset of terminal payoffs of $\mathbb{R}^{2|Z|}$ for which the induced game has a Nash equilibrium outcome with player 1 indifferent between such an outcome and some equilibrium in the excluded game $\mathbb{G}^{1}$ is a semi-algebraic set of dimension lower than $2|Z|$.

Proof. Our previous construction is such that $A_{1}$ is a disjoint union of $C_{1}$ and $C_{1}^{\prime}$ and only considers equilibria $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right)$ and a deviation $b_{1}^{\prime}$ such that the support of $b_{1}$ is $C_{1}$, the support of $b_{2}$ is $A_{2}$, and $b_{1}^{\prime}$ induces a full support $\alpha$ and completely mixes after all $\check{C}_{1}$ at all subsequent information sets. In this case, we consider the projection $\pi: M \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{2|Z|}$ over $\mathbb{R}^{2|Z|}$ and apply Lemma B.1, thus obtaining that $\pi(M)$ is a semi-algebraic set with dimension less than $2|Z|$. For the general case, note that any equilibrium $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}\right)$ and deviation $b_{1}^{\prime}$ can be made to satisfy the restrictions above by eliminating choices that are not in their corresponding support. Since the set of all choices is finite, we only need to take the intersection of finitely many, full-dimensional, semi-algebraic subsets of games to prove the result.

Proposition 4.3 readily follows from the theorem above.

# APPENDIX C. Proof of Lemma 5.10 

The proof of the lemma in Step 2 is divided in three parts. Before we present it, a preliminary fixed-point theoretic result must be established (Lemma C. 1 below). The proof of this auxiliary result resembles closely the proof of Proposition 3.2 in Govindan et al. (2023) with minor changes.

Lemma C.1. For every open neighborhood $W^{1}$ of the graph of the best-reply correspondence $B R^{1}$ of game $\mathbb{G}^{1}$, there are functions $\check{f}, f^{0}: \Sigma^{1} \rightarrow \Sigma^{1}$ such that $\operatorname{Graph}(\check{f}) \subset W^{1},\left.f^{0}\right|_{\Sigma^{1} \backslash \text { int }\left(K^{1,2 \eta}\right)}=$ $\left.\check{f}\right|_{\Sigma^{1} \backslash \text { int }\left(K^{1,2 \eta}\right)}$, and $f^{0}$ has no fixed point in $K^{1,2 \eta}$.

Proof. Fix $W^{1}$ a neighborhood of the graph of the best-reply correspondence $B R^{1}$ of game $\mathbb{G}^{1}$, such that any continuous map $f$ whose graph is in $W^{1}$ has a displacement $\left.d_{f}\right|_{K^{1,2 \eta}}=$ $\left.(i d-f)\right|_{K^{1,2 \eta}}$ with degree 0 .

Denote by $\partial K^{1,2 \eta}$ the boundary of $K^{1,2 \eta}$ relative to the affine space generated by $\Sigma^{1}$. Note that $\left(K^{1,2 \eta}, \partial K^{1,2 \eta}\right)$ is trivially homeomorphic to a ball with boundary. Define $\check{f}_{t}: \Sigma^{1} \rightarrow \Sigma^{1}$ as follows. Letting $\mathrm{r}_{n}^{0}$ be the barycenter of $\Sigma_{n}^{1}$ for each $n$, define $\forall \sigma \in \Sigma^{1}, \check{f}_{t}(\sigma) \equiv(1-t) f(\sigma)+t \mathrm{r}^{0}$. Taking $t>0$ sufficiently small, we ensure that $\partial K^{1,2 \eta}$ has no fixed points of $\check{f}_{t}$, and $K^{1,2 \eta}$ has index 0 w.r.t. $\check{f}_{t}$. We fix such a $t$ and omit the parameter $t$ from $\check{f}_{t}$, denoting it by $\check{f}$. Let $A_{1}$ and $A_{2}$ be, respectively, the hyperplane in $\mathbb{R}^{|S_{1}^{1}|}$ and $\mathbb{R}^{|S_{2}^{0}|}$ through the origin and with normal $(1, \ldots, 1)$, and let $A=\prod_{n} A_{n}$. The map $d_{\check{f}}=i d-\check{f}$ maps $\Sigma^{1}$ into $A$. Therefore, $d_{\check{f}}$ : $\left(K^{1,2 \eta}, \partial K^{1,2 \eta}\right) \rightarrow(A, A-0)$ has degree zero. By the Hopf Extension Theorem (cf. Corollary 8.1.18, Spanier, 1966) there exists a map $\tilde{d}^{0}$ from $K^{1,2 \eta}$ to $A-0$ such that its restriction to $\partial K^{1,2 \eta}$ coincides with $d_{\check{f}}$. Extend $\tilde{d}^{0}$ to the whole of $\Sigma^{1}$ by letting it be $d_{\check{f}}$ outside $K^{1,2 \eta}$.

For each $\sigma \in \Sigma^{1}$, there exists $\zeta \in(0,1]$ such that $\sigma-\zeta \tilde{d}^{0}(\sigma) \in \Sigma^{1}$. Indeed, this is obvious for $\sigma \in K^{1,2 \eta} \backslash \partial K^{1,2 \eta}$, since $\sigma$ belongs to $\Sigma^{1} \backslash \partial \Sigma^{1}$. For $\sigma \in \partial K^{1,2 \eta} \cup\left(\Sigma^{1} \backslash K^{1,2 \eta}\right)$, we can take $\zeta=1$ as $\tilde{d}^{0}=d_{\check{f}}$. Now for each $\sigma$, let $\zeta(\sigma)$ be the largest $\zeta \in[0,1]$ such that $\sigma-\zeta(\sigma) \tilde{d}^{0}(\sigma) \in \Sigma^{1}$. Note that the map $\sigma \mapsto \zeta(\sigma)$ is continuous. Define $f^{0}: \Sigma^{1} \rightarrow \Sigma^{1}$ by $f^{0}(\sigma) \equiv \sigma-\zeta(\sigma) \tilde{d}^{0}(\sigma)$. The map $f^{0}$ is continuous, coincides with $\check{f}$ on $\Sigma^{1} \backslash\left(K^{1,2 \eta} \backslash \partial K^{1,2 \eta}\right)$ and has no fixed point in $K^{1,2 \eta}$.

The reasoning in the three-part proof presented below resembles closely the reasoning presented in the proof of Theorem 3 in GW. For the sake of completeness we include details here, with the necessary explicit modifications required for our setting.

# Notation 

All norms presented from now on are $\ell_{\infty}$-norms. Given a finite game $\mathbb{G}=\left(S_{1}, S_{2}, \mathbb{G}_{1}, \mathbb{G}_{2}\right)$, let $g \in \mathbb{R}^{|S_{1}|+|S_{2}|}$. Denote by $\mathbb{G} \oplus g$ the finite game where pure strategies are $S_{n}, n=1,2$ and payoffs are defined by $\mathbb{G}_{n}\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right)+g_{s_{n}}, n=1,2$. In Part II, we will use an analogous construction: given a continuous function $g: \Sigma \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{|S_{1}|+|S_{2}|}$, where $\Sigma=\Sigma_{1} \times \Sigma_{2}$ and $\Sigma_{n}=\Delta\left(S_{n}\right)$, for each $\sigma \in \Sigma$, the finite game $\mathbb{G} \oplus g(\sigma)$ is then defined. The payoff of a mixed strategy profile $\sigma^{\prime}$ to player $n$ is then $\mathbb{G}_{n}\left(\sigma^{\prime}\right)+\sigma_{n}^{\prime} \cdot g_{n}(\sigma)$, where $g_{n}(\sigma) \in \mathbb{R}^{|S_{n}|}$. Given $\mu>0$ and $\sigma \in \Sigma, \tau \in \Sigma$ is a $\mu$-reply to $\sigma$ if it satisfies: $\forall n, s_{n}, \mathbb{G}_{n}\left(\tau_{n}, \sigma_{-n}\right) \geq \mathbb{G}_{n}\left(s_{n}, \sigma_{-n}\right)-\mu$. A duplicate strategy $\bar{s}_{n}$ in $\mathbb{G}$ is a pure strategy that is equivalent to a mixed strategy $\sigma_{n}$ of $\mathbb{G}$, i.e., for all $m, s_{-n} \in$ $S_{-n}, \mathbb{G}_{m}\left(\bar{s}_{n}, s_{-n}\right)=\mathbb{G}_{m}\left(\sigma_{n}, s_{-n}\right)$.

## C.1. Part I

Lemma C.2. Without loss of generality, game $\mathbb{G}^{1}$ satisfies the following property: for every neighborhood $W^{1}$ of $\operatorname{Graph}\left(\mathrm{BR}^{1}\right)$, there exists a map $h: \Sigma^{1} \rightarrow \Sigma^{1}$ s.t.
(1) $\operatorname{Graph}(h) \cap\left[\left(\Sigma^{1} \backslash K^{1,2 \eta}\right) \times \Sigma^{1}\right] \subseteq W^{1} \cap\left[\left(\Sigma^{1} \backslash K^{1,2 \eta}\right) \times \Sigma^{1}\right]$
(2) For each player $n$, the $n$-th coordinate map $h_{n}$ of $h$ depends only on $\Sigma_{-n}$
(3) $h$ has no fixed point in $K^{1,2 \eta}$

Proof. This lemma's proof parallels the reasoning in Step 1 of GW very closely, with no major changes. We quickly recall the details for completeness. First let $\mathbb{G}^{*}$ be defined by letting $S_{n}^{*}=S_{n}^{1} \times S_{n+1}^{1}$, where $n=1,2$ is taken modulo 2 , be the strategy set of player $n$. For each $n$, and $m \in\{n, n+1\}$, denote the natural projection $p_{n, m}$ from $S_{n}^{*}$ to $S_{m}^{1}$. Define payoffs $\mathbb{G}_{n}^{*}\left(s^{*}\right)=\mathbb{G}_{n}^{1}(s)$, where for each $m, s_{m}=p_{m, m}\left(s_{m}^{*}\right)$. Extend $p_{n, m}$ linearly to $\Delta\left(S_{n}^{*}\right)$ so that $p_{n, m}$ computes the marginal over $S_{m}^{1}$. Let $p: \Sigma^{*} \rightarrow \Sigma^{1}$ be the map $p\left(\sigma^{*}\right)=\left(p_{1,1}\left(\sigma_{1}^{*}\right), p_{2,2}\left(\sigma_{2}^{*}\right)\right)$. The map $p^{*}$ computes the payoff-relevant coordinates of $\sigma^{*}$ in the game $\mathbb{G}^{*}$. Let $P: \Sigma^{*} \times \Sigma^{*} \rightarrow$ $\Sigma^{1} \times \Sigma^{1}$ be defined by $P\left(\sigma^{*}, \tau^{*}\right)=\left(p\left(\sigma^{*}\right), p\left(\tau^{*}\right)\right)$.

Let $\mathrm{BR}^{*}$ denote the best-reply correspondence of game $\mathbb{G}^{*}$. Let $K^{*}$ denote the set of $\mathbb{G}^{*}$ that is equivalent to $K^{1,2 \eta}$. Fix a neighborhood $W^{*}$ of $\operatorname{Graph}\left(\mathrm{BR}^{*}\right)$. For $\mu>0$, consider $W(\mu)=$ $\left\{\left(\sigma^{1}, \tau^{1}\right) \in \Sigma^{1} \times \Sigma^{1} \mid \tau^{1}\right.$ is a $\mu$-reply to $\left.\sigma\right\}$. The collection $\{W(\mu)\}_{\mu>0}$ is a basis of neighborhoods of $\operatorname{Graph}\left(\mathrm{BR}^{*}\right)$. Choose $\mu>0$ such that $P^{-1}(W(\mu)) \subseteq W^{*}$.

Apply now Lemma 5.1 to obtain $f^{0}$ with (i) $\operatorname{Graph}\left(\left.f^{0}\right|_{\Sigma^{1} \backslash K^{1,2 \eta}}\right) \subseteq W(\mu) \cap\left[\left(\Sigma^{1} \backslash K^{1,2 \eta}\right) \times \Sigma^{1}\right]$ and (ii) $f^{0}$ has no fixed point in $K^{1,2 \eta}$. Define now the map $h^{*}: \Sigma^{*} \rightarrow \Sigma^{*}$ such that for each $n, h_{n}^{*}\left(\sigma^{*}\right)=\tau_{n}\left(\sigma^{*}\right) * p_{n+1, n+1}\left(\sigma_{n+1}^{*}\right)$, where $\tau_{n}\left(\sigma^{*}\right) * p_{n+1, n+1}\left(\sigma_{n+1}^{*}\right)$ is a product probability (measure) with

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \tau_{1}^{*}\left(\sigma^{*}\right) \equiv f_{1}^{0}\left(p_{2,2}\left(\sigma_{2}^{*}\right), p_{2,1}\left(\sigma_{2}^{*}\right)\right) \\
& \tau_{2}^{*}\left(\sigma^{*}\right) \equiv f_{2}^{0}\left(p_{1,1}\left(\sigma_{2}^{*}\right), p_{1,2}\left(\sigma_{2}^{*}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that each coordinate map $h_{n}^{*}$ is defined over $\Sigma_{-n}^{*}$ and therefore satisfies (2).

We claim that $\operatorname{Graph}\left(\left.h^{*}\right|_{\Sigma^{*} \backslash K^{*}}\right) \subseteq W^{*} \cap\left(\left[\Sigma^{*} \backslash K^{*}\right] \times \Sigma^{*}\right)$. From (i) above, it follows that $\tau_{n}\left(\sigma^{*}\right)$ is a $\mu$-reply to $p_{-n}\left(\sigma^{*}\right)$. Therefore $\left(p\left(\sigma^{*}\right), \tau\left(\sigma^{*}\right)\right)$ belongs to $W(\mu)$. Hence $\left(\sigma^{*}, h^{*}\left(\sigma^{*}\right)\right) \in$ $P^{-1}(W(\mu)) \subseteq W^{*}$, which concludes the proof of the claim. Therefore, $h^{*}$ satisfies (1).

To conclude the proof of the lemma, suppose now that $\sigma^{*}$ is a fixed point of $h^{*}$. Then $\sigma_{n}^{*}$ is a product strategy with $p_{n, n+1}\left(\sigma_{n}^{*}\right)=p_{n+1, n+1}\left(h_{n}^{*}\left(\sigma_{n}^{*}\right)\right)$. Hence, $p_{n, n}\left(\sigma_{n}^{*}\right)=p_{n, n}\left(h_{n}^{*}\left(\sigma^{*}\right)\right)=$ $f_{n}^{0}\left(p_{-n,-n}\left(\sigma^{*}\right), p_{n-1, n}\left(\sigma_{n-1}^{*}\right)\right)=f_{n}^{0}\left(p\left(\sigma^{*}\right)\right)$. Therefore, $p\left(\sigma^{*}\right)$ is a fixed point of $f^{0}$. Since from (ii) above $f^{0}$ has no fixed point in $K^{1,2 \eta}, \sigma^{*} \notin K^{*}$. So $h^{*}$ satisfies (3).

# C.2. Part II 

Lemma C.3. For any $\delta_{0}>0$, there exists $\delta>0$ and an equivalent game $\hat{\mathbb{G}}^{1}$ to $\mathbb{G}^{1}$ obtained by adding duplicates to $\mathbb{G}^{1}$ such that the following holds: there exists a map $g: \hat{\Sigma}^{1} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{R}$ (where $\left.\widehat{R}=\left|\widehat{S}_{1}\right|+\left|\widehat{S}_{2}\right|\right)$ satisfying:
(1) For each player $n, g_{n}$ depends on $\hat{\Sigma}_{n}^{1}$.
(2) No profile $\bar{\sigma} \in \widehat{K}^{1}$ is an equilibrium of the game $\hat{\mathbb{G}} \oplus g(\bar{\sigma})$.
(3) $\|g(\bar{\sigma})\| \leq \delta_{0}$, for each $\bar{\sigma} \in \hat{\Sigma}^{1} \backslash \operatorname{int}_{\Sigma 1}\left(\widehat{K}^{1,2 \eta}\right)$.
(4) $\|g(\sigma)\| \leq \delta$, for each $\bar{\sigma} \in \widehat{K}^{1,2 \eta}$.

The proof will require a simple auxiliary result whose proof can be found in GW. Let $M$ be a constant satisfying: for each $\sigma, \tau,\left\|\mathbb{G}_{n}^{1}(\sigma)-\mathbb{G}_{n}^{1}(\tau)\right\| \leq M\|\sigma-\tau\|$, for each $n=1,2$.

Lemma C.4. [Lemma, GW] If $\tau_{n}$ is a $\beta_{1}$-reply against $\sigma,\left\|\tau_{n}-\tau_{n}^{\prime}\right\| \leq \beta_{2},\left\|\sigma-\sigma^{\prime}\right\| \leq \beta_{3}$, then $\tau_{n}^{\prime}$ is a $\beta_{1}+M \beta_{2}$-reply to $\sigma$, and $\tau_{n}$ is a $\left(2 M \beta_{3}+\beta_{1}\right)$-reply to $\sigma^{\prime}$.

Proof. See GW.
Lemma C.5. There exists $\delta_{1}>0$ such that for any equivalent game $\hat{\mathbb{G}}^{1}$ to $\mathbb{G}^{1}$ and any $\bar{g} \in$ $\mathbb{R}^{\left|S_{1}\right|+\left|S_{2}\right|}$ with $\|\bar{g}\| \leq \delta_{1}, \hat{\mathbb{G}}^{1} \oplus \bar{g}$ does not have an equilibrium in $\widehat{K}^{1} \backslash \widehat{K}^{1,2 \eta}$.

Proof of Lemma C.5. Observe first that $K^{1} \backslash \operatorname{int}_{\Sigma^{1}}\left(K^{1,2 \eta}\right)$ is a compact set. For each $\sigma \in K^{1} \backslash$ $\operatorname{int}_{\Sigma^{1}}\left(K^{1,2 \eta}\right)$, there exists $\varepsilon(\sigma)>0, \varrho(\sigma)>0, n \in\{1,2\}$ and $s_{n} \in S_{n}$ such that for each $\sigma^{\prime} \in$ $B_{\varepsilon(\sigma)}(\sigma)$, we have

$$
\mathbb{G}_{n}^{1}\left(s_{n}, \sigma_{-n}^{\prime}\right)>\mathbb{G}_{n}^{1}\left(\sigma^{\prime}\right)+\varrho(\sigma)
$$

The balls $\left\{B_{\varepsilon(\sigma)}(\sigma)\right\}_{\sigma \in K^{1} \backslash \operatorname{int}_{\Sigma^{1}}\left(K^{1,2 \eta}\right)}$ form an open cover of $K^{1} \backslash K^{1,2 \eta}$, from which we extract a finite subcover: there exists $\sigma^{1}, \ldots, \sigma^{k}$ with corresponding $\varepsilon\left(\sigma^{i}\right)>0, \varrho\left(\sigma^{i}\right)>0, n_{i} \in\{1,2\}$ and $s_{n_{i}} \in S_{n_{i}}$ such that for each $\sigma^{\prime} \in B_{\varepsilon\left(\sigma^{\prime}\right)}\left(\sigma^{i}\right)$

$$
\mathbb{G}_{n_{i}}^{1}\left(s_{n_{i}}, \sigma_{-n_{i}}^{\prime}\right)>\mathbb{G}_{n_{i}}^{1}\left(\sigma^{\prime}\right)+\varrho\left(\sigma^{i}\right)
$$

Define $\varrho=\min _{i} \varrho\left(\sigma^{i}\right)$. Fix an equivalent game $\hat{\mathbb{G}}^{1}$ to $\mathbb{G}^{1}$, and $\bar{\sigma} \in \widehat{K}^{1} \backslash\left(\operatorname{int}_{\Sigma^{1}} \widehat{K}^{1,2 \eta}\right)$. Let $\sigma$ be the equivalent profile in $\mathbb{G}$. Then there exist $n, s_{n} \in S_{n} \subseteq \hat{S}_{n}$,

$$
\hat{\mathbb{G}}_{n}^{1}\left(s_{n}, \bar{\sigma}_{-n}\right)=\mathbb{G}_{n}^{1}\left(s_{n}, \sigma_{-n}\right)>\mathbb{G}_{n}^{1}(\sigma)+\varrho=\hat{\mathbb{G}}_{n}^{1}(\bar{\sigma})+\varrho
$$

Hence, for any $\bar{g} \in \mathbb{R}^{\left|\hat{S}_{1}\right|+\left|\hat{S}_{2}\right|}$ with $\|\bar{g}\| \leq \frac{\rho}{2}=: \delta_{1}$ :

$$
\hat{\mathbb{G}}_{n}^{1}\left(s_{n}, \bar{\sigma}_{-n}\right)+\bar{g}_{s_{n}}>\hat{\mathbb{G}}_{n}^{1}(\bar{\sigma})+\bar{\sigma}_{n} \cdot \bar{g}_{n}
$$

Therefore, $\bar{\sigma}$ is not an equilibrium of $\hat{\mathbb{G}}^{1} \oplus \bar{g}$.

Proof of Lemma C.3. Fix $0<\delta_{0}<\delta_{1}$, where $\delta_{1}$ is obtained from Lemma C.5. Fix $\eta_{0}=\frac{\delta_{0}}{6 M}$. For each $\sigma$, there exists an open ball $B(\sigma)$ around $\sigma$ of radius strictly less than $\eta_{0}$ such that for each $\sigma^{\prime} \in B(\sigma)$, the set of pure best replies to $\sigma^{\prime}$ is a subset of those that are best replies to $\sigma$. Since the set of best replies for each player $n$ to a strategy profile is the face of $\Sigma_{n}^{1}$ spanned by her pure strategies $\operatorname{BR}\left(\sigma^{\prime}\right) \subseteq \operatorname{BR}(\sigma), \forall \sigma^{\prime} \in B(\sigma)$.

The collection of balls $\{B(\sigma)\}_{\sigma}$ define an open covering of $\Sigma^{1}$. By compactness, there exists a finite set of points $\sigma^{1}, \sigma^{2}, \ldots, \sigma^{k}$ whose corresponding balls form a subcover. For each $\sigma^{i}$ let $W\left(\sigma^{i}\right)$ be the $\eta_{0}$-neighborhood of $\mathrm{BR}^{1}\left(\sigma^{i}\right)$.

Let $W=\bigcup_{i}\left(B\left(\sigma^{i}\right) \times W\left(\sigma^{i}\right)\right)$. The set $W$ is a neighborhood of Graph $\left(\mathrm{BR}^{1}\right)$. From Part I, there exists $h: \Sigma^{1} \rightarrow \Sigma^{1}$ such that: (i) Graph $(h) \cap\left(\Sigma^{1} \backslash K^{1,2 \eta}\right) \times \Sigma^{1} \subset W \cap\left(\Sigma^{1} \backslash K^{1,2 \eta}\right) \times \Sigma^{1}$; (ii) For each player $n$, the coordinate map $h_{n}$ of $h$ depends on $\Sigma_{-n}^{1}$; (iii) $h$ has no fixed point in $K^{1}$.

Let $\tau=h(\sigma)$, where $\sigma \in \Sigma^{1} \backslash K^{1,2 \eta}$. Then there exist $\sigma^{i}, \tau^{i}$ with $\sigma \in B\left(\sigma^{i}\right), \tau^{i}$ is a best reply to $\sigma^{i}$ and $\tau$ is within $\eta_{0}$ of $\tau^{i}$. Therefore, Lemma C. 4 implies that $\tau^{i}$ is a $2 M \eta_{0}$-reply against $\sigma$ and therefore $\tau$ is a $3 M \eta_{0}$-reply against $\sigma$.

Fix now $\alpha>0$ such that if $\sigma \in K^{1,2 \eta}$, then $\|\sigma-h(\sigma)\|>\alpha$. For each $n=1,2$, take a simplicial subdivision $\mathscr{T}_{n}$ of $\Sigma_{n}$ such that: (a) $K_{2}^{1,2 \eta}$ is the space of a subcomplex of $\mathscr{T}_{2}$; (b) the diameter of the subdivision is less than $\eta_{0}$ and $\alpha$; (c) no simplex that intersects $K_{2}^{1,2 \eta}$ intersects the boundary of $K_{2}^{1, \eta}$ w.r.t $\Sigma_{2}^{1}$. Let $T_{n}$ be the set of vertices of $\mathscr{T}_{n}$. Let $T \equiv T_{1} \times T_{2}$.

We now define a game $\overline{\mathbb{G}}^{1}$ that is equivalent to $\mathbb{G}^{1}$. For each player $n$, the pure strategy set of player $n$ is $T_{n}$. The game $\overline{\mathbb{G}}^{1}$ is equivalent to $\mathbb{G}^{1}$ and the mixed strategy set is denoted $\bar{\Sigma}^{1}=\bar{\Sigma}_{1}^{1} \times \bar{\Sigma}_{2}^{1}$.

For each $t_{n} \in T_{n}$, let $S t\left(t_{n}\right)$ denote the star of $t_{n}$ in the simplicial complex $\mathscr{T}_{n}$ and $C l S t\left(t_{n}\right)$ is the closed star of $t_{n}$ with respect to $\mathscr{T}_{n}$. Let $X\left(t_{n}\right) \equiv h_{n}^{-1}\left(C l S t\left(t_{n}\right)\right) \subseteq \Sigma_{-n}^{1}$; let $Y\left(t_{n}\right) \equiv$ $\left\{\sigma_{-n} \in \Sigma_{-n}^{1} \mid\left\|t_{n}-h_{n}\left(t_{n}\right)\right\| \geq 2 \eta_{0}\right\}$. Since the diameter of each simplex of $\mathscr{T}_{n}$ is less than $\eta_{0}$, $X\left(t_{n}\right) \cap Y\left(t_{n}\right)=\varnothing$. Use Urysohn's Lemma to define a function $\pi_{t_{n}}: \Sigma_{-n}^{1} \rightarrow[0,1]$, with $\pi_{t_{n}}^{-1}(1) \equiv$ $X\left(t_{n}\right)$ and $Y\left(t_{n}\right) \subset \pi_{t_{n}}^{-1}(0)$.

Let $R^{\prime}=\left|T_{1}\right|+\left|T_{2}\right|$. We define a map $g: \bar{\Sigma}^{1} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{R^{\prime}}$, by first defining it on $\Sigma^{1}$ and extending to $\bar{\Sigma}^{1}$ by equivalence. Let $v_{n}\left(\sigma_{-n}\right)=\max _{s \in S_{n}} \mathbb{G}_{n}^{1}\left(s, \sigma_{-n}\right)$. If $t_{2} \notin K_{2}^{1,2 \eta}$, we define $g_{t_{2}} \equiv 0$. For any other $t_{2}$ :

$$
g_{t_{2}}\left(\sigma_{1}\right) \equiv \pi_{t_{2}}\left(\sigma_{1}\right)\left[v_{2}\left(\sigma_{1}\right)-\mathbb{G}_{2}^{1}\left(t_{2}, \sigma_{1}\right)+M \eta_{0}\right]
$$

Now, for $\sigma_{2} \in \Sigma_{2}^{1} \backslash \operatorname{int}_{\Sigma_{2}^{1}}\left(K_{2}^{1, \eta}\right)$, define, for each $t_{1} \in T_{1}, g_{t_{1}}\left(\sigma_{2}\right) \equiv 0$. If $\sigma_{2} \in K_{2}^{1,2 \eta}$, let

$$
g_{t_{1}}\left(\sigma_{2}\right) \equiv \pi_{t_{1}}\left(\sigma_{2}\right)\left[v_{1}\left(\sigma_{2}\right)-\mathbb{G}_{1}^{1}\left(t_{1}, \sigma_{2}\right)+M \eta_{0}\right]
$$

Fix $n, t_{n}, \sigma \in \Sigma^{1} \backslash K^{1,2 \eta}$. We want to prove that $0 \leq g_{t_{n}}(\sigma) \leq 6 M \eta_{0}=\delta_{0}$.
If $\sigma_{1} \in Y\left(t_{2}\right)$, then $g_{t_{2}}\left(s_{2}\right)=0$. If $\sigma_{1} \notin Y\left(t_{2}\right)$, then $\left\|t_{2}-h_{2}\left(\sigma_{1}\right)\right\| \leq 2 \eta_{0}$. Since $h_{n}\left(\sigma_{-n}\right)$ is a $3 M \eta_{0}$-reply to $\sigma_{-n}$, Lemma C. 4 implies that $t_{n}$ is a $5 M \eta_{0}$-reply to $\sigma_{-n}$, i.e., $0 \leq f_{n}\left(\sigma_{-n}\right)-$ $\mathbb{G}_{n}\left(t_{n}, \sigma_{-n}\right) \leq 5 M \eta_{0}$. Hence, $0 \leq g_{t_{n}}(\sigma) \leq 6 M \eta_{0}=\delta_{0}$. Hence $g_{t_{2}}\left(\sigma_{1}\right) \in\left[0, \delta_{0}\right]$.

Now assume $\sigma_{2} \in\left(\Sigma_{2}^{1} \backslash \operatorname{int}_{\Sigma_{2}^{1}} K_{2}^{1, \eta}\right) \cup K_{2}^{1,2 \eta}$. Note the union is disjoint. If $\sigma_{2} \in Y\left(t_{1}\right)$, then $g_{t_{1}}\left(\sigma_{2}\right)=0$. If $\sigma_{2} \notin Y\left(t_{1}\right)$, then repeating the same reasoning as above and considering the definition of $g_{t_{1}}$ one gets $g_{t_{1}}\left(\sigma_{2}\right) \in\left[0, \delta_{0}\right]$. Using now Urysohn's Lemma, extend $g_{t_{1}}$ continuously to $\Sigma_{2}^{1}$ so that image of $g_{t_{1}}$ is contained in $\left[0, \delta_{0}\right]$. This proves (3). Note that, in

addition, since $K^{1,2 \eta}$ is compact and $g$ continuous, there exists $\delta>0$ such that $\|g(\sigma)\| \leq \delta$ for each $\sigma \in K^{1,2 \eta}$. This shows (4). It is also clear from the construction of $g$ that it satisfies (1).

To finish the proof we show (2). Suppose $\bar{\sigma} \in \bar{K}^{1,2 \eta}$ is an equilibrium and let $\sigma$ be the corresponding equivalent strategy in $\Sigma^{1}$. Following the exact same reasoning as in the last paragraph of Step 2 of GW, the pure best-replies $T_{n}^{\prime}$ to $\sigma_{-n}$ are those $t_{n}$ for which $\sigma_{-n} \in X\left(t_{n}\right)$. Obviously, there exists at least one such $t_{n}$, i.e., a vertex of the carrier of $h_{n}\left(\sigma_{-n}\right)$ in $\mathscr{T}_{n}$. Hence the distance between $t_{n}$ and $h_{n}\left(\sigma_{-n}\right)$ is $<\alpha$. The support of $\bar{\sigma}_{n}$ being a subset of $T_{n}^{\prime}$ implies that $\left\|\sigma_{n}-h_{n}\left(\sigma_{-n}\right)\right\| \leq \alpha$. This is a contradiction and proves that $\bar{K}^{1,2 \eta}$ contains no profile $\bar{\sigma}$ that is an equilibrium of $\bar{G}^{1} \oplus g(\bar{\sigma})$.

Suppose now that $\bar{\sigma} \in \bar{K}^{1} \backslash \bar{K}^{1,2 \eta}$ and consider the game $\bar{G} \oplus g(\bar{\sigma})$. Then, by construction, $\|g(\bar{\sigma})\| \leq \delta_{0}<\delta_{1}$. Our choice of $\delta_{0}$ then implies that $\bar{\sigma}$ is not an equilibrium of $\bar{G}^{1} \oplus g(\bar{\sigma})$. This concludes the proof of this step.

# C.3. Part III 

We now conclude by proving Lemma 5.10.
Let $\bar{G}^{1}$ to be the game from Lemma C.3, satisfying properties (1)-(4). Note that $\bar{K}^{1,2 \eta}$ is compact, $g$ is continuous and if $\bar{\sigma} \in \bar{K}^{1}$, then $\bar{\sigma}$ is not an equilibrium of $\bar{G} \oplus g(\bar{\sigma})$. There exists then $\zeta>0$ such that no $\bar{\sigma} \in \bar{K}^{1}$ is an equilibrium of $\bar{G} \oplus g$, with $\|g-g(\bar{\sigma})\|<\zeta$. Choose $\zeta>0$ such that:

$$
\left\|g(\bar{\sigma})-g\left(\bar{\sigma}^{\prime}\right)\right\| \leq \zeta, \text { if }\left\|\bar{\sigma}-\bar{\sigma}^{\prime}\right\|<\zeta
$$

Consider now a simplicial subdivision $\mathscr{S}_{n}$ of $\bar{\Sigma}_{n}^{1}$ with diameter less than $\zeta>0$ and satisfying the requirement that no simplex of $\mathscr{S}_{2}$ that intersects $\tilde{\partial} K_{2}^{\prime}$ has a point in common with $\bar{K}^{1, \eta}$.

Let $\mathscr{P}_{n}$ be a polyhedral complex generated by $\mathscr{S}_{n}$, with $\gamma_{n}$ the convex function that is linear on each polyhedron ( $\mathscr{P}_{n}$ refines $\mathscr{S}_{n}$ ) (cf. Appendix B in GW). Consider now the game $\bar{G}$ where the strategy set of each player $n$ is $P_{n}$, the set of vertices of $\mathscr{P}_{n}$. Let $\bar{\Sigma}_{n}$ be the mixed strategies of $\bar{G}$. It is clear that $\bar{G}$ satisfies Lemma 5.10 (1) and (2).

Define now the matrix $A_{n} \in \mathbb{R}^{\left|S_{n}\right| \times\left|P_{n}\right|}$, by letting the column $p_{n} \in P_{n}$ have the coordinates of the mixed strategy $p_{n} \in \bar{\Sigma}_{n}$ in $\bar{S}_{n}$. Therefore, given $\bar{\sigma}_{m}, \bar{\sigma}_{m}=A_{m} \bar{\sigma}_{m}$ gives the equivalent strategy $\bar{\sigma}_{m}$ to $\bar{\sigma}_{m}$ in $\bar{G}$.

For each $n$, let now $B_{n}: P_{-n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{P_{n}}$ be defined by $B_{n}\left(p_{-n}\right)=A_{n}^{T} g_{n}\left(p_{-n}\right)$. We define,

$$
\bar{G}_{n}^{1, \delta}(p) \equiv \bar{G}_{n}^{1}(p)+B_{n, p_{n}}\left(p_{-n}\right)
$$

$\bar{G}^{1, \delta}$ is a $\delta$-perturbation of $\bar{G}^{1}$, which is equivalent to $\bar{G}^{1}$. For $\varepsilon>0$, define:

$$
\bar{G}_{n}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon} \equiv \bar{G}_{n}^{1}(p)+B_{n, p_{n}}\left(p_{-n}\right)-\varepsilon \gamma_{n}\left(p_{n}\right)
$$

$\bar{G}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon}$ is an $\varepsilon$-perturbation of $\bar{G}^{1, \delta}$. Our construction of $g$ in Part II now implies that $\bar{G}^{1, \delta}$ and $\bar{G}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon}$ satisfies Lemma 5.10 (3).

We claim that for sufficiently small $\varepsilon>0$, the game $\bar{G}^{1, \delta, \varepsilon}$ has no equilibrium in $\bar{K}^{1}$, the set equivalent to $\bar{K}^{1}$ (and therefore to $K^{1}$ ). Suppose to the contrary that there exists $\left(\varepsilon_{k}\right)_{k \in \mathbb{N}}$ converging to zero and a corresponding sequence $\bar{\sigma}^{k}$ in $\bar{K}^{1}$. For each $k$, let $\bar{\sigma}^{k}$ be the equivalent profile in $\bar{\Sigma}^{1}$. For each $k$ and each player $n$, if $\bar{\tau}_{n}^{k} \in \bar{\Sigma}_{n}^{1}$ such that $A_{n} \bar{\tau}_{n}^{k}=\bar{\sigma}_{n}^{k}$, then

$\sum_{p_{n} \in P_{n}} \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{k}\left(p_{n}\right) \gamma_{n}\left(p_{n}\right) \geq \sum_{p_{n} \in P_{n}} \tilde{\sigma}_{n}^{k}\left(p_{n}\right) \gamma_{n}\left(p_{n}\right)$. Thus $\tilde{\sigma}_{n}^{k}$ solves the linear programming problem $\min _{\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{k}} \sum_{p_{n} \in P_{n}} \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{k}\left(p_{n}\right) \gamma_{n}\left(p_{n}\right)$ subject to $A_{n} \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{k}=\tilde{\sigma}_{n}^{k}$. Let $L_{n}^{k}$ be the unique polyhedron of $\mathscr{P}_{n}$ that contains $\tilde{\sigma}_{n}^{k}$ in its interior. Since $\gamma_{n}$ is a convex function $\gamma_{n}\left(\tilde{\sigma}_{n}^{k}\right) \leq \sum_{p_{n} \in P_{n}} \tilde{\tau}_{n}^{k}\left(p_{n}\right) \gamma_{n}\left(p_{n}\right)$. Moreover, the construction of $\gamma_{n}$ ensures that this inequality is strict unless the support of $\tilde{\tau}_{n}^{k}$ is included in $L_{n}^{k}$. Therefore Lemma 5.10 (4) is satisfied and the equilibrium strategy $\tilde{\sigma}_{n}^{k}$ assigns positive probability only to points in $L_{n}^{k}$.

Now let $\bar{\sigma}$ be a limit of $\bar{\sigma}^{k}$ as $\varepsilon^{k} \rightarrow 0$, and let $\bar{\sigma}$ be an equivalent mixed strategy. Therefore $\bar{\sigma}$ is an equilibrium of the game $\overline{\mathbb{G}} \oplus b$, where $b_{n, \bar{\delta}_{n}}=\sum_{p_{-n}} g_{n, \bar{\delta}_{n}}\left(p_{-n}\right) \bar{\sigma}_{-n}\left(p_{-n}\right)$. By the arguments above, there exists a polyhedron $P_{n}^{\circ} \in \mathscr{P}_{n}$ such that $\bar{\sigma}_{n}$ assigns positive probability only to points in $P_{n}^{\circ}$. Viewing a vertex $p_{-n}^{*}$ of $P_{-n}^{\circ}$ as a point in $\bar{\Sigma}_{-n}^{1}$, we have

$$
\left\|p_{-n}^{*}-\bar{\sigma}_{-n}\right\|<\zeta \Longrightarrow\left\|g_{n}\left(p_{-n}^{*}\right)-g_{n}\left(\bar{\sigma}_{-n}\right)\right\| \leq \zeta
$$

This implies

$$
\left\|\sum_{p_{-n}} g_{n}\left(p_{-n}\right) \tilde{\sigma}_{-n}\left(p_{-n}\right)-g_{n}\left(\bar{\sigma}_{-n}\right)\right\| \leq \zeta
$$

Letting $\bar{g}_{n} \in \mathbb{R}^{\bar{\beta}_{n}}$ be defined by $\bar{g}_{n, \bar{\delta}_{n}}=\sum_{p_{-n}} g_{n, \bar{\delta}_{n}}\left(p_{-n}\right) \bar{\sigma}_{-n}\left(p_{-n}\right)$. Therefore, $\bar{\sigma}$ is an equilibrium of $\overline{\mathbb{G}} \oplus \bar{g}$. However,

$$
\|\bar{g}-g(\bar{\sigma})\| \leq \zeta
$$

Therefore, $\bar{\sigma} \notin \bar{K}^{1}$, by our assumption on $\zeta$. Therefore, for sufficiently small $\varepsilon>0, \overline{\mathbb{G}}^{1, \bar{\beta}, \varepsilon}$ has no equilibrium in $\bar{K}^{1}$, so Lemma 5.10 (5) is satisfied.

abstract:
We prove the 2-player, generic extensive-form case of the conjecture of
Govindan and Wilson (1997a,b) and Hauk and Hurkens (2002) stating that an
equilibrium component is essential in every equivalent game if and only if the
index of the component is nonzero. This provides an index-theoretic
characterization of the concept of hyperstable components of equilibria in
generic extensive-form games, first formulated by Kohlberg and Mertens (1986).
We also illustrate how to compute hyperstable equilibria in multiple
economically relevant examples and show how the predictions of hyperstability
compare with other solution concepts.
